item.title: Clinical manifestations-pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma
item.description: Clinical manifestations-pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma (NEJM 2019;381:552) Neuroendocrine neoplasm leads to inappropriate and paroxysmal release of adrenergic agents including epinephrine, norepinephrine, and rarely dopamine Classic triad: episodic headaches, palpitations and profuse sweating; only 50% have paroxysmal hypertension and most Pts do not have three classic sx Paroxysms can be triggered by meds (eg, Œ≤-blockers), abdominal manipulation Up to 40% of pheos/paragangliomas thought to have underlying genetic etiology; genetic testing frequently recommended Associated with MEN2A/2B, von Hippel Lindau, NF1, familial paraganglioma (mutations in succinate dehydrogenase gene B, C and D), MAX or TMEM127 mutations

item.title: Clinical manifestations-Portal vein thrombosis PVT
item.description: Clinical manifestations-Portal vein thrombosis (PVT) acute: abd pain, fever, variceal bleed or asx w/ incidental finding on U/S or CT. If mesenteric vein involved may p/w intestinal infarct.

item.title: Clinical manifestations-Screening for latent TB
item.description: Clinical manifestations-Screening for latent TB (Lancet 2016;387:1211) Constitutional symptoms are common in all manifestations, but may be absent Primary TB pneumonia: middle or lower lobe consolidation, ¬± effusion, ¬± cavitation TB pleurisy: pulmonary effusion ¬± pericardial and peritoneal effusions secondary to granuloma breakdown and local inflammation; can occur in primary or reactivation Reactivation TB pulmonary disease: upper lobe infiltrate ¬± volume loss ¬± cavitation Milliary TB: diffuse millet seed-sized lesions, more common in immunosupp.

item.title: Compensation-for-Acid-Base-Disorders

item.description: Complications-acute aortic syndromes (occur in ~20%; Circ 2010;121:e266; Lancet 2015;385:800) Freq assess (sx, BP, UOP), pulses, labs (Cr, Hb, lactic acid), imaging (~7 d or sooner if ‚àÜs) Uncontrolled BP or persistent pain may indicate complication/extension Progression: propagation of dissection, ‚Üë aneurysm size, ‚Üë false lumen size Rupture: pericardial sac ‚Üí tamponade (avoid pericardiocentesis unless PEA); blood in pleural space, mediast.

item.title: Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration CVVH
item.description: Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) Hemofiltration rather than dialysis. Blood under pressure passes down one side highly permeable membrane filtering H2O and solutes via TMP gradient (convective clearance); filtrate discarded.

item.title: Contraindications to Fibrinolysis
item.description: Contraindications to Fibrinolysis Absolute Contraindications *Any prior ICH *Intracranial neoplasm, aneurysm, AVM *Ischemic stroke or closed head trauma w/in 3 mo; head/spinal surg.

item.title: Contrast-induced acute kidney injury
item.description: Contrast-induced acute kidney injury Definition increase in the creatinine of 0.5mg/dL or a 25% increase from basline w/i 3 days after the contrast media and abscense of alternative cause (CIAKI) (NEJM 2019;380:2146) natural history 24-48h increase after exposure and peak at 3-5 days resolves in 7 to 10 days if prolonged duration: look for other cause, e.

item.title: Controller medications
item.description: Controller medications (JAMA 2020;324:2301) ICS Rx of choice. Superior to LAMA if sputum w/ ‚â•2% eos (NEJM 2019;380:2009). PO steroids may be needed for severely uncontrolled asthma; avoid if possible b/c of systemic side effects.

item.title: COP cryptogenic organizing PNA
item.description: COP cryptogenic organizing PNA Patchy, migratory consolidations; subpleural & peribronchial. Excessive proliferation of granulation tissue in small airways and alveolar ducts.

item.description: Coronary angiography Immediate/urgent coronary angiography (w/in 2 h) if refractory/recurrent angina or hemodynamic or electrical instability Routine angiography (aka ‚Äúinvasive strategy‚Äù) = coronary angiography for all

item.title: Coronary artery bypass grafting CABG -related MI
item.description: Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)-related MI is arbitrarily defined as elevation of cTn values >10 times the 99th percentile URL in patients with normal baseline cTn values.

item.description: Coronary-angiography-for-SIHD High-risk noninvasive testing results suggestive of left main or multivessel CAD Angina that is refractory to optimal medical therapy Uncertain dx after noninvasive testing, occupational need (eg, pilot) Unexplained heart failure or ‚Üì EF

item.title: coronavirus covid-19
item.description: coronavirus (covid-19) Microbiology & epidemiology Person-to-person transmission via respiratory particles; asx & pre-sx transmission can occur Incubation period: up to 14 days, median time of 4‚Äì5 days from exposure to sx onset Presentation Ranges from asx to severe illness.

item.title: Correction of overanticoagulation
item.description: Correction of overanticoagulation (Circ 2021;143:e72) Risk from major bleeding must be weighed against risk of valve thrombosis Not bleeding: if INR 5‚Äì10, withhold warfarin Bleeding: PCC (or FFP); reversal agent for DOACs; ¬± low-dose (1 mg) vit K IV if on VKA

item.title: Corticosteroids for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
item.description: Corticosteroids for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (inhaled, ICS): ~11% ‚Üì in exacerbations & slows ‚Üì FEV1; no Œî in mortality (Lancet 2016;387:1817).

item.title: CRC screening
item.description: CRC screening (JAMA 2021;325:1978) Colonoscopy gold standard. Other options: FOBT/FIT yearly, flex sig q5y or flex sig q10y + FIT every year, fecal DNA testing (eg, Cologuard) q3y or CT colonography q5y Start screening in average risk Pts at age 45 (typically q10y unless abnl found) If ‚äï FHx, start age 40, or 10 y before age of dx in youngest family member, repeat q5y

item.title: Criteria-Hepatorenal syndrome HRS
item.description: Criteria-Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) (1) cirrhosis w/ ascites; (2) acute kidney injury (serum Cr ‚Üë ‚â•0.3 mg/dL w/in 48 h or ‚â•50% ‚Üë in serum Cr from baseline; Gut 2015;64:531) (3) √ò improvement in Cr after d/c diuretic & volume expansion (1 g/kg/d of albumin √ó 2 d); (4) √ò shock (prerenal azotemia/ATN); (5) √ò nephrotoxic meds; (6) √ò intrinsic kidney disease

item.title: crohn‚Äôs disease
item.description: crohn‚Äôs disease (Lancet 2017;389:1741) [[Clinical manifestations-crohn‚Äôs disease]] [[Diagnosis-crohn‚Äôs disease]] [[Complications-crohn‚Äôs disease]] Prognosis Variable at 1 y: ~50% in remission, ~20% flare, ~20% low activity, ~10% chronic active At 20 y, majority will have required some surgery; overall life expectancy is slightly ‚Üì

item.title: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
item.description: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis (Lancet 2012;379:348; Nat Rev Dis Primers 2018;4:11) Cryoglobulins: proteins that precipitate from serum or plasma on exposure to cold and redissolve on rewarming, characterized by their composition; a/w chronic immune stimulation and/or lymphoproliferation Distinguish from cryofibrinogenemia = proteins (eg, fibrin, fibrinogen) that precipitate only from plasma; found in autoimmune dis, malignancies, infxns; unclear clinical significance [[Types of Cryoglobulinemia]] (J Autoimmun 2019;105:102313) Epidemiology: ~1/100,000, but prevalence varies with HCV rates; ‚ôÄ >‚ôÇ Etiologies (idiopathic in ~10%) Hematologic diseases: multiple myeloma, MGUS, Waldenstr√∂m‚Äôs, chronic lymphocytic leukemia in type I; B-cell lymphomas or solid-organ malignancies in type II Infxns (types II & III): viral (HCV [>80% RNA ‚äï], HBV, HIV, HAV, EBV, CMV), bacterial (endocarditis, strep, etc.

item.title: Cryoprecipitate
item.description: Cryoprecipitate Enriched for fibrinogen, vWF, VIII, and XIII. 1st line for fibrinogen <100 mg/dL. For bleeding in vWD factor XIII deficiency, use if other products not available.

item.title: Cryptococcus
item.description: Cryptococcus Epidemiology: immunosupp. most susceptible (espec. AIDS, transplant recipients, and cirrhosis); can occur in healthy hosts (esp C. gattii) Clinical manifestations CNS (meningoencephalitis): subacute HA, fever, meningismus, CN abnl, ¬± stupor Other sites: pulm.

item.title: Cryptococcus neoformans
item.description: Cryptococcus neoformans A common infectious cause of subacute and chronic meningoencephalitis associated with raised intracranial pressure in immunocompromised patients is Cryptococcus neoformans.

item.title: CSF leak
item.description: CSF leak headache clear fluid leaking from the nose or ear. Some CSF leaks may heal with conservative treatments such as bed rest.

item.title: culture negative-bacterial endocarditis
item.description: culture negative-bacterial endocarditis abiotrophic strep [[HACEK]] (Haemophilus para-influenzae & aphrophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella), T. whipplei [[Bartonella]], [[Coxiella burnetii]] Chlamydia Legionella [[Brucella]] (JAMA 2007;297:1354; Annals 2007;147:829; J Clin Microbiol 2012;50:216)

item.title: Culture-negative neutrocytic ascites CNNA
item.description: Culture-negative neutrocytic ascites (CNNA) cell counts suggest infxn but cx ‚äñ. No recent abx, w/o other explanation for counts. Often do have [[Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis]] and should be treated with empiric regimen.

item.title: Cushing‚Äôs Syndrome
item.description: Cushing‚Äôs Syndrome Cushing‚Äôs syndrome = cortisol excess Cushing‚Äôs disease = Cushing‚Äôs syndrome 2¬∞ to pituitary ACTH hypersecretion [[Etiologies of hypercortisolism]] [[Clinical manifestations-Cushing‚Äôs Syndrome]] [[Diagnosis Cushing‚Äôs Syndrome]] [[Treatment of Cushing‚Äôs syndrome]]

item.title: Cutaneous arteritis
item.description: Cutaneous arteritis Sometimes called “benign cutaneous [[Polyarteritis nodosa]]” cPAN can nevertheless result in significant morbidity due to painful skin nodules, digital infarcts, ulcerations, and other complications

item.title: cutaneous leukocytoclastic angiitis
item.description: cutaneous leukocytoclastic angiitis Occurs 7‚Äì10 days after certain medications (penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfonamides, phenytoin, allopurinol) or infections (eg, HCV, HIV). Palpable purpura, no visceral involvement.

item.title: Cutaneous-complications of HIV AIDS
item.description: Cutaneous-complications of HIV AIDS Eosinophilic folliculitis; warts (HPV); HSV & VZV; MRSA SSTI; scabies; candidiasis; eczema; prurigo nodularis; psoriasis; drug eruption; subungual onychomycosis Molluscum contagiosum (poxvirus): 2‚Äì5 mm pearly papules w/ central umbilication Kaposi‚Äôs sarcoma (KSHV or HHV8): red-purple nonblanching nodular lesions Bacillary angiomatosis (disseminated Bartonella): friable violaceous vascular papules

item.title: CXR of Diagnostic studies-chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
item.description: CXR of Diagnostic studies-chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (see Radiology inserts): hyperinflation, flat diaphragms, ¬± interstitial markings & bullae

item.title: Cyanide-toxicology
item.description: Cyanide-toxicology Coma, seizure, metabolic acidosis, hypotension IV Na nitrite and Na thiosulfate IV hydroxocobalamin Call local Poison Control for assistance with management.

item.title: Cyclic vomiting syndrome
item.description: Cyclic vomiting syndrome acute recurrent vomiting; a/w marijuana use, personal or FHx of migraine. Acute Rx: antiemetics, IVF, sumatriptan (1st line, followed by aprepitant x 3 d), BDZs; prevention: TCAs/AEDs; avoid marijuana.

item.title: cynosis
item.description: cynosis central cyanosis can be detected reliably when the SaO2 has fallen to 85%; in others, particularly in dark-skinned persons, it may not be detected until it has declined to 75%

item.title: Decreased GFR-hyperkalemia
item.description: Decreased GFR-hyperkalemia Any cause of oliguric or anuric AKI or any cause of end-stage renal disease

item.title: Definition and causes-acute mesenteric ischemia
item.description: Definition and causes-acute mesenteric ischemia Reduced or absent blood flow to small intestine, typically caused by arterial (ie, SMA or its branches) occlusion or transient hypoperfusion or less often by venous occlusion

item.title: Definition and clinical manifestations of Migraine
item.description: Definition and clinical manifestations of Migraine (Lancet 2018;391:1315 & Continuum 2021;27:586) [[POUNDing Mnemonic]] Epidemiology: affects 15% of women and 6% of men; onset usually by 30 y

item.title: Definition and epidemiology
item.description: Definition and epidemiology (Lancet 2018;391:783) Chronic inflam disorder w/ airway hyperresponsiveness + variable airflow obstruction Affects 5‚Äì10% population; ~85% of cases by age 40 y

item.title: Definition and epidemiology-bronchiectasis
item.description: Definition and epidemiology-bronchiectasis (NEJM 2002;346:1383) Obstructive airways disease of bronchi and bronchioles, chronic transmural inflammation w/ airway dilatation and thickening, collapsibility, mucus plugging w/ impaired clearance

item.title: Definition and epidemiology-chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
item.description: Definition and epidemiology-chronic obstructive pulmonary disease Progressive airflow limitation caused by airway and parenchymal inflammation

item.title: definition and etiologies of peptic ulcer disease
item.description: definition and etiologies of peptic ulcer disease (BMJ 2019;367:5495) Ulcers (break in mucosal lining >5 mm) & erosions (<5 mm) in stomach and duodenum Principal risk factors: H.

item.title: Definition and etiologies-chronic kidney disease CKD
item.description: Definition and etiologies-chronic kidney disease (CKD) (Lancet 2021;10302:786) GFR <60 for ‚â•3 mo and/or kidney damage (albuminuria, structural abnormality)

item.title: Definition and pathophysiology-anaphylaxis
item.description: Definition and pathophysiology-anaphylaxis (Ann Emerg Med 2006;47:373) Severe, rapid onset (mins to hrs), potentially life-threatening systemic allergic response

item.title: Definition and pathophysiology-cystic fibrosis
item.description: Definition and pathophysiology-cystic fibrosis (NEJM 2015;372:351) Autosomal recessive genetic disorder due to mutations in chloride channel (CFTR gene)

item.title: Definition and pathophysiology-hemoptysis
item.description: Definition and pathophysiology-hemoptysis Expectoration of blood or blood-streaked sputum Massive hemoptysis: >100 mL/h or >500 mL in 24 h; massive hemoptysis usually from tortuous or invaded bronchial arteries [[Etiologies-hemoptysis]]

item.title: Definition Clinical Manifestations-HIV AIDS
item.description: Definition Clinical Manifestations-HIV AIDS Acute HIV: rash, lymphadenopathy, fever, oral ulcers, pharyngitis, myalgias, diarrhea Presents ~2‚Äì6 wk after exposure; not all HIV infections result in symptoms of acute HIV AIDS: HIV + CD4 <200/mm3 or AIDS-defining opportunistic infection (OI) or malignancy

item.title: Definition etiologies peptic ulcer disease
item.description: Definition etiologies peptic ulcer disease Ulcers (break in mucosal lining >5 mm) & erosions (<5 mm) in stomach and duodenum

item.title: Definition of Constipation
item.description: Definition of Constipation Defined as dissatisfaction w/ defecation or (per Rome IV): ‚â•2 of following during last 3‚Äì6 mos ‚â•25% of the time: straining, lumpy/hard stools, incomplete evacuation, sensation of anorectal obstruction, manual maneuvers to facilitate defecation, stool frequency <3/wk

item.title: Definition of fever and neutropenia
item.description: Definition of fever and neutropenia Fever: single oral temp ‚â•38.3¬∞C (101¬∞F) or ‚â•38¬∞C (100.4¬∞F) for ‚â•1 h Neutropenia: ANC <500 cells/¬µL or <1000 cells/¬µL with predicted nadir <500 cells/¬µL

item.title: Definition, precipitants, pathophysiology-hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state
item.description: Definition, precipitants, pathophysiology-hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (Med Clin North Am 2017;101:587) Extreme hyperglycemia (w/o ketoacidosis) + hyperosm. + Œî MS in T2D (typically elderly) Precip same as for DKA, but also include dehydration and renal failure Hyperglycemia ‚Üí osmotic diuresis ‚Üí vol depletion ‚Üí prerenal azotemia ‚Üí ‚Üë glc, etc.

item.title: Definition-acute kidney injury AKI
item.description: Definition-acute kidney injury (AKI) (KDIGO 2012;2:1) Stages in ICU correspond to ‚Üë hospital mortality and LOS (Crit Care Med 2009;37:2552) Diagnostic criteria Increase in serum creatinine of ‚â•0.

item.title: Definition-acute liver failure
item.description: Definition-acute liver failure Acute liver injury + coagulopathy + encephalopathy w/o preexisting liver dis. (<26 wks) Fulminant if encephalopathy <8 wks from jaundice onset, subfulminant if 8‚Äì26 wks

item.title: Definition-Antiphospholipid syndrome
item.description: Definition-Antiphospholipid syndrome dx requires ‚â•1 clinical & ‚â•1 laboratory criteria Clinical: thrombosis (any) or complication of pregnancy (‚â•3 spont. abortions before 10 wk or ‚â•1 fetal loss after 10 wk or premature birth before 34 wk)

item.title: Definition-cirrhosis
item.description: Definition-cirrhosis (Dig Dis 2016;34:374; NEJM 2016;375:767; J Hep 2016;64:717) Definition fibrosis & regenerative nodules causing distortion of hepatic architecture

item.title: Definition-diabetes mellitus
item.description: Definition-diabetes mellitus (Diabetes Care 2022;45:S256) HbA1c ‚â•6.5 fasting glc ‚â•126 mg/dL glc 2 h after [[OGTT]] ‚â•200 mg/dL √ó 2 (for any test) or single random glc ‚â•200 mg/dL w/ classic sx of hyperglycemia; all tests equally reasonable (nb, may be ‚äï on one test but not another); OGTT preferred during preg Blood glc higher than normal, but not frank DM (‚Äúprediabetics,‚Äù ~40% U.

item.description: Definition-glomerulonephritis Lancet 2016;387:2036; JASN 2016;27:1278) ÂèÉËÄÉ‚û°Ô∏è Mayo clinic/renal pathology society consensus report on pathologic classification, diagnosis, and reporting of GN ÂèÉËÄÉ‚û°Ô∏è Primary glomerulonephritides

item.title: Definition-necrotizing soft-tissue infections
item.description: Definition-necrotizing soft-tissue infections Fulminant tissue destruction, systemic toxicity & high mortality. Surgical emergency. May include cellulitis, fasciitis, myositis, myonecrosis (gas gangrene).

item.title: Definition-nephrotic syndrome
item.description: Definition-nephrotic syndrome ( JASN 2014;25:2393) Podocyte injury (effacement) ‚Üí loss of proteins (albumin, ATIII, Ig) Clinically: proteinuria >3.

item.title: Definition-syncope
item.description: Definition-syncope Symptom of sudden transient loss of consciousness due to global cerebral hypoperfusion If CPR or cardioversion required, then SCD and not syncope (different prognosis) Presyncope = prodrome of light-headedness without LOC

item.title: Definitions heart failure
item.description: Definitions heart failure ÂêÑÁ®ÆÂÆöÁæ© Failure of heart to pump blood forward at rate sufficient to meet metabolic demands of peripheral tissues, or ability to do so only at abnormally high cardiac filling pressures Low output (‚Üì cardiac output) vs.

item.title: Definitions-accessory pathways wolff-parkinson-white
item.description: Definitions-accessory pathways (wolff-parkinson-white) Accessory pathway (bypass tract) of conducting myocardium connecting atria & ventricles, allowing impulses to bypass normal AVN delay Pre-excitation (WPW) pattern: ‚Üì PR interval, ‚Üë QRS width w/ Œ¥ wave (slurred onset, can be subtle).

item.title: Definitions-acid-base disturbances
item.description: Definitions-acid-base disturbances Acidemia ‚Üí pH <7.36, alkalemia ‚Üí pH >7.44; pH = 6.10 + log([HCO3]/[0.03xPCO2]) Acidosis ‚Üí process that ‚Üë [H+] or ‚Üì pH by ‚Üì HCO3 or ‚Üë PaCO2 Alkalosis ‚Üí process that ‚Üì [H+] or ‚Üë pH by ‚Üë HCO3 or ‚Üì PaCO2 Primary disorders: metabolic acidosis or alkalosis, respiratory acidosis or alkalosis [[Compensation-for-Acid-Base-Disorders]] The physiological approach uses the carbonic acid‚Äìbicarbonate buffer system.

item.title: Definitions-acute aortic syndromes
item.description: Definitions-acute aortic syndromes (Circ 2010;121:e266; Eur Heart J 2012;33:26) Aortic dissection: intimal tear ‚Üí blood extravasates into Ao media (creates false lumen) Intramural hematoma (IMH): vasa vasorum rupture ‚Üí medial hemorrhage that does not communicate with aortic lumen; 6% of aortic syndromes; clinically managed as AoD Penetrating ulcer: atherosclerotic plaque penetrates elastic lamina ‚Üí medial hemorrhage

item.title: Definitions-and-clinical-manifestations
item.description: Definitions-and-clinical-manifestations Pneumonia: s/s (fever, cough, purulent sputum, dyspnea) + new infiltrate on chest imaging Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP): pneumonia acquired outside of hospital setting [[Hospital-acquired pneumonia]] (HAP): pneumonia acquired ‚â•48 hrs after hospitalization [[Ventilator-associated pneumonia]] (VAP): pneumonia acquired ‚â•48 hrs after intubation Lung empyema: accumulation of pus in pleural space Lung abscess: parenchymal necrosis with confined cavitation [[Aspiration pneumonitis]]: acute lung injury after inhalation of gastric contents without infection, though bacterial infection can occur within 24‚Äì72 hrs of injury

item.title: Definitions-aortic aneurysms
item.description: Definitions-aortic aneurysms True (‚â•50% dilation of all 3 layers; <50% = ectasia) vs. false (rupture w/in adventitia) Location: root (annuloaortic ectasia), thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA), thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm (TAAA), abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) Type: fusiform (circumferential dilation) vs.

item.title: Definitions-sepsis and shock
item.description: Definitions-sepsis and shock Sepsis [!tldr] TLDR Sepsis is defined as life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection.

item.title: Definitions-skin and soft tissue infections
item.description: Definitions-skin and soft tissue infections Cellulitis: infection of dermis and subcutaneous tissue characterized by erythema, warmth, tenderness, and swelling; often occurs as a result of skin breaches (JAMA 2016;315:3) ËúÇÁ™©ÁπîÁÇéÔºö‰ª•Á¥ÖÊñë„ÄÅÁôºÁÜ±„ÄÅÂ£ìÁóõÂíåËÖ´ËÑπÁÇ∫ÁâπÂæµÁöÑÁúüÁöÆÂíåÁöÆ‰∏ãÁµÑÁπîÊÑüÊüìÔºõÁ∂ìÂ∏∏Âõ†ÁöÆËÜöÁ†¥Ë£ÇËÄåÁôºÁîü (JAMA 2016;315:3) Skin abscess: subcutaneous collection of pus Staph toxic shock syndrome: rapid onset fever, rash, hypotension, and multiorgan injury.

item.title: Definitions-tuberculosis
item.description: Definitions-tuberculosis Primary: new Mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB) in a na√Øve host; symptomatic or asymptomatic; 90% of infected normal hosts will never develop clinically evident disease Latent: well-controlled infection without clinical or radiographic evidence of active disease; can persist for years to decades Reactivated: activation of latent; more likely in the setting of immunosuppression.

item.title: Definitions-urinary tract infections
item.description: Definitions-urinary tract infections Asymptomatic bacteriuria: presence of bacteria in urine without signs or sx of infection Uncomplicated: confined to bladder. No upper tract or systemic infection signs.

item.title: Definitions-venous thromboembolism
item.description: Definitions-venous thromboembolism Superficial thrombophlebitis: * pain, tenderness, erythema along superficial vein [[deep vein thrombosis]] Proximal = thrombosis of iliac, femoral, or popliteal veins (nb, ‚Äúsuperficial‚Äù femoral vein part of deep venous system).

item.title: Delayed hemolytic
item.description: Delayed hemolytic : generally less severe than acute hemolytic; 5‚Äì7 d after transfusion, but can be severe ‚Üí hyperhemolysis. Due to undetected allo-Abs vs.

item.description: delta-delta (Œî/Œî = ŒîAG/ŒîHCO3) to assess if there is an additional metabolic acid-base disturbance; ŒîAG = (calculated AG ‚Äì expected AG), ŒîHCO3 = (24 ‚Äì HCO3) Œî/Œî = 1‚Äì2 ‚Üí pure AG metabolic acidosis Œî/Œî <1 ‚Üí AG metabolic acidosis and simultaneous non-AG acidosis Œî/Œî >2 ‚Üí AG metabolic acidosis and simultaneous metabolic alkalosis For pure lactic acidosis Œî/Œî 1.

item.description: Diagnosis gastroesophageal reflux (Annals 2015;163:ITC1; Nat Rev Gastro Hepatol 2016;13:501) Clinical diagnosis based on sx and response to empiric trial of PPI (‚ÄúPPI test‚Äù) EGD if: √ò response to PPI or alarm features: dysphagia, vomiting, ‚Üì wt, anemia, age >60 If dx uncertain & EGD nl ‚Üí esoph manometry w/ 24-h pH monitoring ¬± impedance to dx: ‚ÄúNonerosive reflux disease‚Äù: no erosion, ulceration or Barrett‚Äôs; ¬Ω abnl pH.

item.title: Diagnosis of migraine
item.description: Diagnosis of migraine Record medical history Apply diagnostic criteria Consider differential diagnoses Examine patient to exclude other causes Use neuroimaging only when a secondary headache disorder is suspected [[54321-PUMA-ÂòîÊÄï]]

item.title: Diagnosis of SVT Type
item.description: Diagnosis of SVT Type (NEJM 2012;367:1438) Onset Abrupt on/off argues against sinus tachycardia Rate Not dx b/c most can range from 140‚Äì250 bpm, but: ST usually <150; AFL often conducts 2:1 ‚Üí vent.

item.title: Diagnosis of Thrombotic microangiopathies
item.description: Diagnosis of Thrombotic microangiopathies unexplained thrombocytopenia (typically <20k) + MAHA ‚Üí sufficient for dx ‚äï schistocytes (>2‚Äì3/hpf), ‚äñ Coombs, normal PT/PTT & fibrinogen ‚Üë‚Üë LDH (tissue ischemia + hemolysis), ‚Üë indirect bili.

item.title: Diagnosis-anaphylaxis
item.description: Diagnosis-anaphylaxis any of the three following criteria Acute illness with skin ¬± mucosal involvement (rash, flushing, hives), AND at least one of: Respiratory compromise (wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, hypoxemia)

item.title: Diagnosis-aseptic meningitis
item.description: Diagnosis-aseptic meningitis Obtain LP for CSF analysis: lymphocytic pleocytosis common in viral etiologies (see Typical CSF Findings in Meningitis table above) Consider CSF cytology and MRI brain/spine to evaluate for malignancy Consider serum autoimmune and serum viral testing in appropriate settings if CSF is unrevealing and there is no improvement with empiric treatment

item.description: Diagnosis-clostridioides difficile infection (Ann Intern Med 2018;169:49) Only test if symptomatic (diarrhea, s/s of colitis); test liquid stool (unless concern for ileus)

item.title: Diagnosis-crohn‚Äôs disease
item.description: Diagnosis-crohn‚Äôs disease Ileocolonoscopy + bx along w/ small bowel assessment (eg, MR-enterography) Small bowel/ileitis (~25%), ileocolonic (~50%), colonic (~25%); isolated upper tract rare

item.title: Diagnosis-Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase
item.description: Diagnosis-Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase smear may show RBC Heinz bodies (oxidized Hb) that result in bite cells once removed by spleen; ‚Üì G6PD levels (may be normal after acute hemolysis because older RBCs have already lysed and young RBCs may still have near-normal levels)

item.description: Diagnosis-hyperaldosteronism (JCEM 2016;101:1889; Endo Metab Clin 2019;48:681; J Clin Endo Met 2021;106:2423) 5‚Äì10% of Pts w/ HTN; ‚à¥ screen if HTN + hypoK, adrenal mass, refractory/early onset HTN Screening: ‚Üì‚Üì renin, aldo >15‚Äì20 ng/dL, plasma aldo:renin ratio (>20 if 1¬∞); obtain 8 a.

item.title: Diagnosis-necrotizing soft-tissue infections
item.description: Diagnosis-necrotizing soft-tissue infections Clinical dx is sufficient to initiate urgent surgical exploration Aspiration of necrotic center; BCx; Gram stain; lactate, AST, & CK for deep tissue necrosis Imaging: noncontrast CT, but do not delay Rx/surgery (Arch Surg 2010;145:452) Microbiologic dx from Gram stain and culture of surgical specimens LRINEC score: ‰∏ªË¶ÅÊòØLabÁöÑÂèÉËÄÉ If high suspicion for necrotizing fasciitis through clinical history and physical exam, do not calculate a LRINEC score and go straight to operative debridement.

item.description: Diagnosis-osteomyelitis (JAMA 2008;299:806) ÂèÉËÄÉ‚û°Ô∏è Does this patient with diabetes have osteomyelitis of the lower extremity? Crucial to obtain cx data of causative organism to avoid long-term empiric abx Bone biopsy or tissue cx obtained surgically or via percutaneous biopsy (send aerobic, anaerobic, mycobacterial, and fungal cultures + pathology) unless ‚äï blood cx.

item.title: Diagnosis-sexually transmitted infections
item.description: Diagnosis-sexually transmitted infections (MMWR 2021;70:1; JAMA 2022;327:161) Syphilis: 1st step is treponemal test: IgG to T. pallidum. ‚äï for life.

item.title: Diagnosis-skin and soft tissue infections
item.description: Diagnosis-skin and soft tissue infections [[Differential Diagnosis of Cellulitis]] Clinical diagnosis based on physical examination Cultures from intact skin are not helpful and should not be performed (CID 2014;59:e10) BCx are typically low yield (~5‚Äì10%) Ultrasound can be used to identify deep abscesses and facilitate drainage.

item.title: Diagnosis-ulcerative colitis
item.description: Diagnosis-ulcerative colitis Colonoscopy: involves rectum (95%) & extends prox., circumfer., & contig. w/in colon Location: proctitis (30‚Äì60%), L-sided (15‚Äì45%) and extensive (pancolitis; 15‚Äì35%)

item.title: Diagnostic and staging evaluation of lung cancer
item.description: Diagnostic and staging evaluation of lung cancer [[Staging of lung cancer]] [[5-y survival of lung cancer]] Imaging: CT w/ contrast of chest & abd/pelvis to assess for mets (adrenal, liver, bones).

item.title: Diagnostic approach-fever syndromes
item.description: Diagnostic approach-fever syndromes Thorough history including ROS, PMH/PSH, immunizations, including from childhood Fever curve (holding antipyretics); look at trend/pattern. Less likely to mount fever if: ESRD/ESLD, extremes of age, protein calorie malnutrition, immunosupp.

item.title: Diagnostic clues that favor VT
item.description: Diagnostic clues that favor VT (assume until proven o/w) Prior MI, CHF, or LV dysfunction best predictors that WCT is VT (Am J Med 1998;84:53) Hemodynamics and rate do not reliably distinguish VT from SVT MMVT is regular, but initially it may be slightly irregular, mimicking AF w/ aberrancy; grossly irregularly irregular rhythm suggests AF w/ aberrancy or pre-excitation ECG features that favor VT (Circ 2016;133:e506) AV dissociation (independent P waves, capture or fusion beats) proves VT Very wide QRS (>140 ms in RBBB-type or >160 in LBBB-type); extreme axis deviation QRS morphology atypical for BBB (longest precordial RS >100 ms and R wider than S) RBBB-type: absence of tall R‚Ä≤ (or presence of monophasic R) in V1, r/S ratio <1 in V6 LBBB-type: onset to nadir >60 ms in V1, q wave in V6 Initial R wave in aVR; concordance (QRS in all precordial leads w/ same pattern/direction)

item.title: Diagnostic evaluation of breast cancer
item.description: Diagnostic evaluation of breast cancer Palpable breast mass: age <30 y ‚Üí observe for resolution over 1‚Äì2 menstrual cycles; age <30 y, unchanging mass ‚Üí U/S ‚Üí aspiration if mass not simple cyst; age >30 y or solid mass on U/S or bloody aspirate or recurrence after aspiration ‚Üí mammo (detect other lesions) and either fine-needle asp.

item.title: Diagnostic evaluation of fever and neutropenia
item.description: Diagnostic evaluation of fever and neutropenia Exam: skin, oropharynx, lung, perirectal area, surgical & catheter sites; avoid rectal exam Studies: U/A, blood (periph & through each indwelling catheter port), urine, & sputum cx; for localizing s/s ‚Üí ‚úì stool (C.

item.title: Diagnostic evaluation of hypercoagulable states
item.description: Diagnostic evaluation of hypercoagulable states (not routinely required for initial VTE; NEJM 2017;377:1177) APC resistance screen; prothrombin PCR test; functional assays for proteins C and S, ATIII; homocysteine level; factor VIII levels; anticardiolipin and lupus anticoagulant Ab.

item.title: Diagnostic evaluation of thrombocytopenia
item.description: Diagnostic evaluation of thrombocytopenia H&P: meds, infxns, underlying conditions, splenomegaly, lymph nodes, bleeding hx CBC with differential: isolated thrombocytopenia vs.

item.title: Diagnostic evaluation-anemia
item.description: Diagnostic evaluation-anemia History: bleeding, systemic illness, drugs, exposures, alcohol, diet (including pica), FHx CBC w/ diff.; RBC params incl.

item.description: Diagnostic evaluation-hemolytic anemias ‚Üë retic count (RI >2%), ‚Üë LDH, ‚Üì hapto (83% Se, 96% Sp), ‚Üë indirect bili, ‚úì vit C & Cu

item.description: Diagnostic evaluation-hypopituitary syndromes Hormonal studies Chronic: ‚Üì target gland hormone + ‚Üì or (inappropriately) normal trophic pituitary hormone Acute: will develop defic.

item.title: diagnostic studies of peptic ulcer disease
item.description: diagnostic studies of peptic ulcer disease Testing for H. pylori: stool Ag, urea breath testing (UBT) or EGD + rapid urease test (RUT) False ‚äñ Ag, UBT, RUT if on abx, bismuth, PPI; ‚à¥ stop prior to testing if possible Serology: ‚Üì utility, useful only to exclude infection in lower prevalence areas EGD (definitive dx): if fail empiric Rx or alarm features (see ‚ÄúGERD‚Äù); bx GU to r/o malig & H.

item.title: Diagnostic studies-constrictive pericarditis
item.description: Diagnostic studies-constrictive pericarditis ECG: nonspecific, AF common (up to 33%) in advanced cases CXR: calcification (MTb most common), espec in lateral view (although not specific) Echocardiogram: ¬± thickened pericardium, ‚Äúseptal bounce‚Äù = abrupt displacement of septum during rapid filling in early diastole Cardiac catheterization: atria w/ Ms or Ws (prominent x and y descents) ventricles: dip-and-plateau or square-root sign (rapid ‚Üì pressure at onset of diastole, rapid ‚Üë to early plateau) discordance between LV & RV pressure peaks during respiratory cycle (Circ 1996;93:2007) CT or MRI: thickened pericardium (>4 mm; Se ~80%) w/ tethering (Circ 2011;123:e418)

item.description: Diagnostics for active TB (CID 2017;64:11) Pulmonary TB: common CXR findings discussed above; induced sputum AFB smear & culture (3 samples at least 8 h apart) ¬± NAAT/ PCR (GeneXpert); consider bronchoscopy + BAL ¬± transbronchial biopsy.

item.title: Differential Diagnosis of Delirium
item.description: Differential Diagnosis of Delirium Toxins Prescription medications: especially those with anticholinergic properties, narcotics, and benzodiazepines Drugs of abuse: alcohol intoxication and alcohol withdrawal, opiates, ecstasy, LSD, GHB, PCP, ketamine, cocaine, ‚Äúbath salts,‚Äù marijuana and its synthetic forms Poisons: inhalants, carbon monoxide, ethylene glycol, pesticides Metabolic Conditions Electrolyte disturbances: hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia, hyponatremia, hypernatremia, hypercalcemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia Hypothermia and hyperthermia Pulmonary failure: hypoxemia and hypercarbia Liver failure/hepatic encephalopathy Renal failure/uremia Cardiac failure Vitamin deficiencies: B12, thiamine, folate, niacin Dehydration and malnutrition Anemia Infections Systemic infections: urinary tract infections, pneumonia, skin and soft tissue infections, sepsis CNS infections: meningitis, encephalitis, brain abscess Endocrine Conditions Hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism Hyperparathyroidism Adrenal insufficiency Cerebrovascular Disorders Global hypoperfusion states Hypertensive encephalopathy Focal ischemic strokes and hemorrhages (rare): especially nondominant parietal and thalamic lesions Autoimmune Disorders CNS vasculitis Cerebral lupus Neurologic paraneoplastic and autoimmune encephalitis Seizure-Related Disorders Nonconvulsive status epilepticus Intermittent seizures with prolonged postictal states Neoplastic Disorders Diffuse metastases to the brain Gliomatosis cerebri Carcinomatous meningitis CNS lymphoma Hospitalization Terminal end-of-life delirium

item.description: diverticulosis Definition & pathophysiology (Aliment Pharm Ther 2015;42:664) Acquired herniations of colonic mucosa & submucosa in areas where vasa recta penetrate Abnormal motility and ‚Üë intraluminal pressure cause protrusion of colonic wall Epidemiology Risk factors: ‚Üì fiber, chronic constipation, obesity, smoking, physical inactivity, EtOH, NSAIDs, ‚Üë age (10% if <40 y; 50‚Äì66% if >80 y); ‚Üë red meat consumption Left side (90%, mostly sigmoid) >R side of colon (except in Asia where 75‚Äì85% R-sided) Clinical manifestations Usually asx; 5‚Äì15% develop diverticular hemorrhage (see ‚ÄúGIB‚Äù) and 10‚Äì25% diverticulitis Limited data for ‚Üë fiber diet or avoiding nuts/seeds (Thera Adv Gastro 2016;9:213)

item.title: Etiologies-adrenal insufficiency
item.description: Etiologies-adrenal insufficiency Primary = adrenocortical disease = Addison‚Äôs disease autoimmune: isolated or in assoc w/ APS (see table on page 7-2) infection: TB, CMV, histoplasmosis, paracoccidioidomycosis vascular: hemorrhage (usually in setting of sepsis), adrenal vein thrombosis, HIT, trauma metastatic disease: (90% of adrenals must be destroyed to cause insufficiency) deposition diseases: hemochromatosis, amyloidosis, sarcoidosis drugs: azole antifungals, etomidate (even after single dose), rifampin, anticonvulsants Secondary = pituitary failure of ACTH secretion (but adrenal aldosterone intact b/c RAA axis) any cause of primary or secondary hypopituitarism (see ‚ÄúPituitary Disorders‚Äù) glucocorticoid therapy (can occur after ‚â§2 wk of ‚Äúsuppressive doses‚Äù; dose effect variable; even <10 mg of prednisone daily chronically can be suppressive) megestrol (a progestin with some glucocorticoid activity)

item.title: Etiologies-aseptic meningitis
item.description: Etiologies-aseptic meningitis (Neurology 2006;66:75) Viral: enteroviruses are most common cause (summer/fall; rash, GI, URI sx), HIV, HSV, VZV, mumps (parotitis), lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (rodent exposure), encephalitis viruses, adenovirus, polio, CMV, EBV, WNV Focal bacterial infection: brain/epidural/subdural abscess, CNS septic thrombophlebitis Partially treated bacterial meningitis Other infectious: TB, fungal (cryptococcus, coccidiodes), Lyme, syphilis, leptospirosis Neoplasm: intracranial tumors (or cysts), lymphomatous or carcinomatous meningitis Drug-induced meningitis: NSAIDs, IVIG, antibiotics (TMP-SMX, PCN), anti-epileptics Systemic autoimmune illness: SLE, sarcoidosis, Beh√ßet‚Äôs, Sj√∂gren‚Äôs syndrome, RA Mollaret‚Äôs: recurrent lymphocytic meningitis, spontaneously resolving (often HSV-2)

item.title: Etiologies-hyperthyroidism
item.description: Etiologies-hyperthyroidism Graves‚Äô disease (60‚Äì80% of thyrotoxicosis) Thyroiditis: thyrotoxic phase of subacute (granulomatous) or painless (lymphocytic) Toxic adenomas (single or multinodular goiter) Extremely rare: TSH-secreting pituitary tumor or pituitary resistant to thyroid hormone (‚Üë TSH, ‚Üë free T4) Misc: amiodarone, iodine-induced, thyrotoxicosis factitia, struma ovarii (3% of ovarian dermoid tumors and teratomas), tumors (eg, choriocarcinoma) secreting hCG (weak bioactivity against TSH-R), large deposits of metastatic follicular thyroid cancer

item.title: Etiologies-pancytopenia
item.description: Etiologies-pancytopenia Hypocellular bone marrow (nl cellularity ~100 ‚Äì age): aplastic anemia, hypoplastic MDS Cellular bone marrow: MDS, aleukemic leukemia, PNH, severe megaloblastic anemia

item.title: Etiologies-solitary pulmonary nodule
item.description: Etiologies-solitary pulmonary nodule Benign (70%) Granuloma (80%): TB, histo, coccidio Hamartoma (10%) Bronchogenic cyst, AVM, pulm infarct Echinococcosis, ascariasis, aspergilloma GPA, rheumatoid nodule, sarcoidosis Lipoma, fibroma, amyloidoma

item.title: Etiologies-syncope

item.title: Etiologies-wide-complex tachycardias WCTS
item.description: Etiologies-wide-complex tachycardias (WCTS) (Lancet 2012;380:1520) Ventricular tachycardia (VT): accounts for 80% of WCT in unselected population SVT conducted with aberrancy: either fixed BBB, rate-dependent BBB (usually RBBB), conduction via an accessory pathway or atrially triggered ventricular pacing

item.title: Etiology-aortic-regurgitation
item.description: Etiology-aortic-regurgitation Valve disease (43%): rheumatic (usually mixed AS/AR + MV disease); bicuspid AoV (natural hx: ‚Öì‚Üí normal, ‚Öì‚Üí AS, ‚Öô‚Üí AR, ‚Öô‚Üí endocarditis ‚Üí AR); infective endocarditis; valvulitis (RA, SLE, certain anorectics & serotonergics, XRT) Root disease (57%): HTN, aortic aneurysm/dissection, annuloaortic ectasia (ie, Marfan), aortic inflammation (GCA, Takayasu‚Äôs, ankylosing spond.

item.title: Etiology-aortic-stenosis
item.description: Etiology-aortic-stenosis Calcific: predominant cause in Pts >70 y; risk factors: HTN, ‚Üë LDL-C, ‚Üë Lp(a), ESRD Congenital (ie, bicuspid AoV w/ premature calcification): cause in 50% of Pts <70 y Rheumatic heart disease (AS usually accompanied by AR and MV disease) AS mimickers: subvalvular (HCMP, subaortic membrane) or supravalvular stenosis

item.title: Etiology-constrictive pericarditis
item.description: Etiology-constrictive pericarditis (Circ 2011;124:1270) Any cause of pericarditis (~1‚Äì2% incidence overall after acute pericarditis) Highest risk w/ TB, bacterial, neoplastic, XRT, connective tissue, postcardiac surgery Viral/idiopathic, b/c most common cause of pericarditis, also account for signif proportion

item.title: Etiology-epidural abscess
item.description: Etiology-epidural abscess Hematogenous spread (‚Öî): skin infection, soft tissue (dental abscess), or endocarditis Direct extension (‚Öì): vertebral osteo, sacral ulcer, spinal anesthesia or surgery, LP Risk factors: IVDU diabetes, renal failure, alcoholism, immunosuppression S.

item.title: Etiology-mitral-regurgitation
item.description: Etiology-mitral-regurgitation Valve disease (43%): rheumatic (usually mixed AS/AR + MV disease); bicuspid AoV (natural hx: ‚Öì‚Üí normal, ‚Öì‚Üí AS, ‚Öô‚Üí AR, ‚Öô‚Üí endocarditis ‚Üí AR); infective endocarditis; valvulitis (RA, SLE, certain anorectics & serotonergics, XRT) Root disease (57%): HTN, aortic aneurysm/dissection, annuloaortic ectasia (ie, Marfan), aortic inflammation (GCA, Takayasu‚Äôs, ankylosing spond.

item.title: Etiology-mitral-stenosis
item.description: Etiology-mitral-stenosis Rheumatic heart disease (RHD): fusion of commissures ‚Üí ‚Äúfish-mouth‚Äù valve from autoimmune rxn to Œ≤ strep infxn; seen largely in developing world (Circ 2020;142:e337) Mitral annular calcification: encroachment upon leaflets ‚Üí fxnal MS; espec in ESRD Postsurgical repair or post-TEER w/ reduced mitral valve area (MVA) Congenital, infectious endocarditis w/ large lesion, myxoma near MV, thrombus Valvulitis (eg, SLE, amyloid, carcinoid) or infiltration (eg, mucopolysaccharidoses)

item.title: Etiology-osteomyelitis
item.description: Etiology-osteomyelitis (Lancet 2004;364:369) Hematogenous: S. aureus; mycobacterial infection of vertebral body = Pott‚Äôs disease Contiguous focus (may be acute or chronic) Open fracture, orthopedic surgery, etc.

item.title: Etiology-pericardial tamponade
item.description: Etiology-pericardial tamponade Any cause of pericarditis but espec malignancy, infectious, uremia, ascending AoD, myocardial rupture, periprocedural complication, trauma, post-cardiotomy Rapidly accumulating effusions most likely to cause tamponade b/c no time for pericardium to stretch (eg, to ‚Üë compliance) and accommodate ‚Üë intrapericardial fluid volume

item.title: Evaluation in patients without diabetes- but have hypoglycemia
item.description: Evaluation in patients without diabetes- but have hypoglycemia (JCEM 2009;94:709) If clinically ill: take measures to avoid recurrent hypoglycemia; ‚úì BUN, Cr, LFTs, TFTs, prealbumin; IGF-I/IGF-II ratio when appropriate If otherwise healthy: 72-h fast w/ monitored blood glc; stop for neuroglycopenic sx At time of hypoglycemia: insulin, C peptide (‚Üë w/ insulinoma and sulfonylureas, ‚Üì w/ exogenous insulin), Œ≤-OH-butyrate, sulfonylurea levels At end of fast, give 1 mg glucagon IV and measure response of plasma glc before feeding

item.description: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (40%; CJASN 2017;12:502). Primary: permeability factor. Secondary adaptive (hyperfiltration, sickle cell, obesity, anabolic steroids, OSA, ‚Üë protein, vesico-ureteral reflux); meds/toxins (IFN, bisphosphonates, NSAIDs, heroin), viral (COVID-19, HIV) or genetic (ApoL1 mutation in AA; JASN 2015;26:1443).

item.title: Follow-up, treatment response and failure of Migraine
item.description: Follow-up, treatment response and failure of Migraine Use headache calendars Assess effectiveness and adverse events When outcomes are suboptimal, review diagnosis, treatment strategy, dosing and adherence When treatment fails, re-evaluate before changing Referral to specialist care should be reserved for patients whose condition is diagnostically challenging, difficult to treat or complicated by comorbidities

item.title: Follow-up-aortic aneurysms
item.description: Follow-up-aortic aneurysms (Circ 2010;121:e266; Nat Rev Cardiol 2011;8:92; JAMA 2013;309:806) Expansion rate ~0.1 cm/y for TAA, ~0.3‚Äì0.4 cm/y for AAA TAA: 6 mo after dx to ensure stable, and if stable, then annually (Circ 2005;111:816) AAA: <4 cm q2‚Äì3y; 4‚Äì5.

item.description: Fourth Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction (2018) myocardial cell death due to prolonged ischemia Increases in cTnI values have not been reported to occur following injury to noncardiac tissues.

item.description: Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias (Chest 2012;141:e495S; NEJM 2015;373:252) Type I Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias(not clin. signif) Direct effect of heparin (non-immune) Incidence 10‚Äì20% After 1‚Äì4 d of heparin therapy Platelet nadir: >100,000/¬µL Sequelae: None Can continue heparin and observe Type II Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias (clinically significant HIT) Immune (Ab)-mediated IgG against plt factor 4‚Äîheparin complex 1‚Äì3% with UFH, 0‚Äì0.

item.description: Hepatic encephalopathy (HE) (NEJM 2016;375:1660; Hepatology 2014; 60:715) Pathogenesis: failure of liver to detoxify NH3 + other substances (eg, ADMA; J Hepatol 2013;58:38) that cause cerebral edema, ‚Üì O2 consumption, ‚Üë ROS ‚Üí brain dysfxn

item.title: Hepatic hydrothorax
item.description: Hepatic hydrothorax 2¬∞ diaphragmatic defect; often unilateral, R >L, ¬± ascites Treatment: avoid chest tube (‚Üë complications); Rx same as ascites (TIPS if refractory).

item.title: Hepatitis A
item.description: Hepatitis A (ssRNA; 30‚Äì45% of acute viral hepatitis in U.S; MMWR 2018;67:1208) Transmission & RFs: fecal‚Äìoral route; contam. food, water, shellfish; daycare ctr; intl travel Incubation: 2‚Äì6 wk; no chronic carrier state; once antibody forms ‚Üí lifelong immunity Sx: ‚Üì appetite, malaise, fever, N/V, RUQ pain, jaundice; rarely ALF (‚Üë w/ chronic HCV) Diagnosis: acute hepatitis = ‚äï IgM anti-HAV; past exposure = ‚äï IgG anti-HAV (‚äñIgM) Rx for acute HAV: supportive care; refer to liver txplnt center if acute liver failure Vaccinate if: MSM, IVDU, chronic liver disease, international travel; Havrix (2 doses)

item.title: Hepatitis B
item.description: Hepatitis B [[Symptoms of HBV Clinical Presentation]] [[Laboratory Abnormalities of HBV Clinical Presentation]] [[Serologic and virologic tests]] [[Extrahepatic Manifestations of HBV Clinical Presentation]] [[Staging of HBV Clinical Presentation]] [[Prevention of HBV Clinical Presentation]] [[HBV Natural History]] Transmission: blood (IVDU, transfusion), sexual, perinatal (vertical) Incubation: 6 wk‚Äì6 mo (mean 12‚Äì14 wk) Acute infxn: 70% subclinical, 30% jaundice, <1% acute liver failure (up to 60% mortality) Chronic infxn: HBsAg ‚äï >6 mo in <5% of adult-acquired (‚Üë if immunosupp), >90% of perinatal; ~40% chronic HBV ‚Üí cirrhosis (‚Üë risk w/ HCV, HDV, or HIV coinfxn, EtOH) HCC: ‚Üë risk if cirrhosis, ‚äï FHx HCC, African >20 y old, Asian ‚ôÇ >40 y old or ‚ôÄ >50 y old, or >40 y old w/ ‚Üë ALT ¬± HBV DNA >2000.

item.title: hepatitis B virus Rx duration
item.description: hepatitis B virus Rx duration (1) HBeAg ‚äï immune active w/o cirrhosis: if seroconversion (HBeAg ‚äñ, anti- HBe ‚äï), can stop after 1 y if ALT nl & HBV DNA suppressed or until HBsAg clears; (2) HBeAg ‚äñ immune reactivation: indefinite; (3) cirrhosis: indefinite

item.title: Hepatitis C
item.description: Hepatitis C (ssRNA; ~10% of acute viral hepatitis in U.S.; Lancet 2015;385:1124) [[Recommended First-Line Oral Direct-Acting Antiviral (DAA) Regimens]]

item.title: hepatitis C virus acute infxn
item.description: hepatitis C virus acute infxn 80% subclinical; 10‚Äì20% sx hepatitis w/ jaundice; acute liver failure rare; prob of spont clearance a/w IL28B & HLA class II genotypes (Annals 2013;158:235)

item.title: hepatitis C virus extrahepatic syndromes
item.description: hepatitis C virus extrahepatic syndromes mixed cryoglobulinemia, porphyria cutanea tarda, lichen planus, leukocytoclastic vasculitis, thyroiditis, MPGN, IPF, NHL and monoclonal gammopathies

item.title: hepatitis C virus Monitoring on Rx
item.description: hepatitis C virus Monitoring on Rx CBC, INR, LFTs, GFR, HCV VL prior to starting Rx. PIs contraindicated if decomp. liver dx (ascites, encephalopathy) or CPS ‚â•7.

item.title: hepatitis C virus recommended First-Line Oral Direct-Acting Antiviral DAA Regimens
item.description: hepatitis C virus recommended First-Line Oral Direct-Acting Antiviral (DAA) Regimens Sofosbuvir & velpatasvir Genotypes 1‚Äì6, 12 weeks Rx Glecaprevir & pibrentasvir Gentotypes 1‚Äì6; 8 weeks Rx

item.title: hepatitis C virus Serologic, virologic, & genetic tests
item.description: hepatitis C virus Serologic, virologic, & genetic tests (screen all adults [‚úì anti-HCV] JAMA 2020;323:970) anti-HCV (ELISA): ‚äï in 6 wk, does not = recovery or immunity; can be ‚äñ after recovery

item.title: hepatitis C virus Treatment indications
item.description: hepatitis C virus Treatment indications ( www.hcvguidelines.org) (Lancet 2019;393:1453; Hepatology 2020;71:686) Acute: if no spont. clearance at 12‚Äì16 wk, can Rx w/ same regimens for chronic HCV Chronic: ‚Üì HCC & mortality.

item.title: Hepatitis D
item.description: Hepatitis D (RNA; Gastro 2019:156;461) Transmission: blood or sexual; endemic in Africa & E. Europe. Generally requires host to already have HBV infxn in order to cause co-infection or superinfection; in rare cases (immunosupp s/p liver transplant) can replicate autonomously.

item.title: Hepatitis E
item.description: Hepatitis E (ssRNA; World J Gastro 2016;22:7030; Gastro Clin N Am 2017;46:393) Most common cause of acute viral hepatitis in endemic areas

item.title: Hepatopulmonary syndrome HPS
item.description: Hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS) (Dig Dis Sci 2015;60:1914, Hepatology 2021;74:1014) Abnl gas exchange (A-a gradient ‚â•15 or PaO2 <80) caused by intrapulmonary vascular dilatations leading to intrapulmonary shunting (improves with O2) S/S: platypnea-orthodeoxia (dyspnea & hypoxia w/ sitting up), clubbing, spider angiomas Dx w/ contrast echo showing ‚Äúlate‚Äù A-V shunting (contrast in LA 3‚Äì6 cycles after RA) Rx: O2; potential embolization if large vessel on CT, TIPS, liver tx only definitive Rx

item.title: Hepatorenal syndrome HRS
item.description: Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) Reference Hepatology 2021;74:1014 Gastro 2016;150:1525 AJKD 2013;62:1198 Pathophysiology: splanchnic vasodilation and renal vasoconstriction w/ ‚Üì renal blood flow

item.title: HER2

item.description: Horner‚Äôs syndrome ÊòØ‰∏ÄÁ®ÆÂΩ±ÈüøË∫´È´î‰∏ÄÂÅ¥ÁöÑÈù¢ÈÉ®ÂíåÁúºÁùõÁöÑÁñæÁóÖ„ÄÇ ÈÄôÊòØÁî±ÊñºÂæûÂ§ßËÖ¶Âà∞È†≠ÈÉ®ÂíåÈ†∏ÈÉ®ÁöÑÁ•ûÁ∂ìÈÄöË∑ØÁöÑÁ†¥Â£ûÂºïËµ∑ÁöÑ„ÄÇ ÈÄöÂ∏∏ÔºåÈúçÁ¥çÁ∂úÂêàÂæµÁöÑÈ´îÂæµÂíåÁóáÁãÄÂåÖÊã¨ TL;DR Áû≥Â≠îÂ§ßÂ∞èÁöÑÈôç‰ΩéÔºå ÁúºÁûº‰∏ãÂûÇ ËáâÈÉ®ÂèóÂΩ±ÈüøÂÅ¥ÁöÑÂá∫Ê±óÊ∏õÂ∞ë„ÄÇ Common Sings A persistently small pupil (miosis) A notable difference in pupil size between the two eyes (anisocoria) Little or delayed opening (dilation) of the affected pupil in dim light Drooping of the upper eyelid (ptosis) Slight elevation of the lower lid, sometimes called upside-down ptosis Sunken appearance of the affected eye Little or no sweating (anhidrosis) on the affected side of the face anhidrosis:no sweating

item.description: hyperthyroidism [[Etiologies-hyperthyroidism]] Clinical manifestations Restlessness, sweating, tremor, moist warm skin, fine hair, tachycardia, AF, weight loss, ‚Üë frequency of stools, menstrual irregularities, hyperreflexia, osteoporosis, stare and lid lag (due to sympathetic overactivity) Apathetic thyrotoxicosis: seen in elderly who can present with lethargy as only sx Laboratory testing ‚Üë free T4 and total T3; ‚Üì TSH (except in TSH-secreting tumors) RAIU scan is very useful study to differentiate causes (see table on page 7-3); cannot do if recent IV contrast or amio load b/c iodine blocks uptake, so ‚úì autoantibodies instead Rarely need to ‚úì for autoantibodies except in pregnancy (to assess risk of fetal Graves‚Äô) May see hypercalciuria ¬± hypercalcemia, ‚Üë Aœï, anemia [[Graves‚Äô disease]] [[Thyroiditis]] [[Treatment-hyperthyroidism]] (Thyroid 2016;26:1343; JCEM 2020;105:3704) Subclinical hyperthyroidism (NEJM 2018;378:2411) Mild ‚Üì TSH and normal free T4 with only subtle or no sx ~15% ‚Üí overt hyperthyroidism in 2 y; ‚Üë risk of AF, CHD, fracture (JAMA 2015;313:2055) Rx controversial: consider if TSH <0.

item.title: hypothyroidism
item.description: hypothyroidism Etiologies Primary (>90% of cases of hypothyroidism; ‚Üì free T4, ‚Üë TSH) Goitrous: [[Hashimoto‚Äôs thyroiditis]] (after hyperthyroid phase of thyroiditis), iodine deficiency, lithium, amiodarone Nongoitrous: surgical destruction, s/p radioactive iodine or XRT, amiodarone Secondary (central): ‚Üì free T4; TSH low, inappropriately nl, or slightly high (although functionally inactive due to abnormal glycosylation); due to hypothalamic or pituitary failure Hashimoto‚Äôs thyroiditis Clinical manifestations (Annals 2020;173:ITC1) Early: weakness, fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, headache, depression, cold intolerance, weight gain, constipation, menorrhagia, dry skin, coarse brittle hair, brittle nails, carpal tunnel syndrome, delayed DTRs (‚Äúhung up‚Äù reflexes), diastolic HTN, hyperlipidemia Late: slow speech; hoarseness; loss of outer third of eyebrows; myxedema (nonpitting skin thickening due to ‚Üë glycosaminoglycans); periorbital puffiness; bradycardia; pleural, pericardial, & peritoneal effusions; atherosclerosis Myxedema crisis: vide infra Diagnostic studies (Lancet 2017;390:1550) ‚Üì free T4; ‚Üë TSH in 1¬∫ hypothyroidism; ‚äï antithyroid Ab (TPO) in Hashimoto‚Äôs thyroiditis May see hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, anemia, ‚Üë LDL, ‚Üì HDL and ‚Üë CK Screening recommended for pregnant women [[Treatment of overt hypothyroidism]] (Endocrine 2019;66:18) [[Subclinical hypothyroidism]] (NEJM 2017;376:2556; item.description: Initial evaluation of change in mental status see [[Stepwise Evaluation of a Patient with Delirium]] History (witness & background crucial): tempo, premorbid sx (eg, focal neuro deficits, HA, infxn, pain, falls), medical conditions (eg, dementia, epilepsy, onc, cardiac, psych, infection/immune status), accompanied by head trauma, current meds (eg, sedatives, opioids, anticoag, anticonvulsants, immunosuppressants), drug/alcohol use General exam: VS, breathing pattern (eg, Cheyne-Stokes), tongue bite (seizure), nuchal rigidity (meningitis, SAH; do not test if c/f trauma/cervical spine fx), ecchymoses, rash, signs of head trauma (eg, Battle sign, raccoon eyes, hemotympanum, CSF rhinorrhea), asterixis, liver disease stigmata, embolic phenomena/endocarditis, s/s drug use Neuro exam

item.description: initial test of hypophosphatemia serum calcium, vitamin D, and parathyroid hormone levels; arterial blood gas; urine phosphorus and creatinine levels; fractional excretion of phosphorus; fractional excretion of phosphorus < 5% suggests a nonrenal mechanism (intracellular uptake or gastrointestinal); x-ray, if osteomalacia is suspected.

item.title: Initial treatment-clostridioides difficile infection
item.description: Initial treatment-clostridioides difficile infection (CID 2021;73:5; Am J Gastro 2021;116:1124) If possible, d/c abx ASAP; stop antimotility agents & [[cholestyramine]] if using (binds vanco) Fidaxomicin is now preferred over vancomycin regardless of severity; may be limited by $ Mild-mod: fidaxomicin 200 mg BID (‚Üì recurrence rate) or vanco 125 mg PO q6h √ó 10 d Severe (any of the following: >12 BM/d, Temp >103¬∞F, WBC >15, HoTN, ICU care required, ileus): as above; could consider PO+PR vanco Fulminant disease: vanco 500 mg PO qid + MNZ 500 mg IV q8h; consider FMT If worsening (ileus, ‚Üë WBC, ‚Üë lactate, shock, toxic megacolon, peritonitis): abd CT & urgent surgical consult - subtotal colectomy, diverting loop ileostomy or colonic lavage If need to cont abx, cont C.

item.title: ischemic colitis
item.description: ischemic colitis Definition & pathophysiology Nonocclusive disease 2¬∞ to Œîs in systemic circulation or anatomic/fxnal Œîs in local mesenteric vasculature; often underlying etiology unknown, frequently seen in elderly ‚ÄúWatershed‚Äù areas (splenic flexure & rectosigmoid) most susceptible; 25% involve R side; confers worse prognosis (Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2015;13:1969) Clinical manifestations, diagnosis, & treatment Usually p/w cramping LLQ pain w/ overtly bloody stool; fever and peritoneal signs should raise clinical suspicion for infarction Disease spectrum: reversible colopathy (35%), transient colitis (15%), chronic ulcerating colitis (20%), resulting stricture (10%), gangrene (15%), fulminant colitis (<5%) Dx: flex sig/colonoscopy or CT abd/pelvis to make diagnosis; r/o IBD, infectious colitis Treatment: bowel rest, IV fluids, broad-spectrum abx, serial abd exams; surgery for infarction, fulminant colitis, hemorrhage, failure of med Rx, recurrent sepsis, stricture Resolution w/in 48 h w/ conservative measures occurs in >50% of cases

item.title: KEYNOTE-181
item.description: KEYNOTE-181 Purpose: Patients with advanced esophageal cancer have a poor prognosis and limited treatment options after first-line chemotherapy. Patients and methods: In this open-label, phase III study, we randomly assigned (1:1) 628 patients with advanced/metastatic squamous cell carcinoma or adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, that progressed after one prior therapy, to pembrolizumab 200 mg every 3 weeks for up to 2 years or chemotherapy (investigator’s choice of paclitaxel, docetaxel, or irinotecan).

item.description: Loop diuretics (NEJM 2017;377:1964) Drugs: furosemide (Lasix), torsemide, bumetanide (Bumex), ethacrynic acid [[Mechanisms-Loop diuretics]] Dosing: bioavailability PO furosemide ~50%, PO torsemide & bumetanide ~90% 40 mg IV = 80 mg PO Lasix = 20 mg PO/IV torsemide = 1 mg IV/PO bumetanide Dose furosemide bid-qid; qd dosing can yield initial diuresis, but then anti-natriuresis.

item.title: Low-voltage
item.description: Low-voltage QRS amplitude (R + S) <5 mm in all limb leads & <10 mm in all precordial leads

item.title: lumbar puncture after brain imaging
item.description: lumbar puncture after brain imaging A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head is frequently ordered by clinicians prior to performing a lumbar puncture (LP) to rule out an intracranial abnormality with elevated intracranial pressure

item.title: Major-risk-factor-modification-stable ischemic heart disease
item.description: Major-risk-factor-modification-stable ischemic heart disease Lipids: statin (typically high-intensity) ¬± ezetimibe & PCSK9i (see ‚ÄúDyslipidemia‚Äù) BP <130/80 (see ‚ÄúHypertension‚Äù); in SIHD may opt for ACEI and Œ≤B (if angina) Diabetes management (qv): HbA1c ‚â§7% and consider GLP1RA or SGLT2i Smoking cessation; influenza vaccine Diet (‚Üë vegetables, fruits, whole grains; ‚Üì saturated fat, trans fatty acids, sweets, red meat, Na); target BMI 18.

item.title: Malignancy workup-adrenal incidentalomas
item.description: Malignancy workup-adrenal incidentalomas CT and MRI characteristics may suggest adenoma vs. carcinoma Benign features: unenhanced CT <10 Hounsfield units or CT contrast-medium washout >50% at 10 min; size <4 cm; smooth margins, homogenous and hypodense appearance; can follow such incidentalomas w/ periodic scans Suspicious features: size ‚â•4 cm or ‚Üë size on repeat scan; >10 Hounsfield units on CT, irregular margins, heterogeneous, dense or vascular appearance; h/o malignancy or young age.

item.description: Mallory-Weiss tear GE jxn lacerations due to vomiting ‚Üí ‚Üë intraabd pressure & shearing Often self-resolve; Rx‚Üí antiemetics, PPI, endoscopic therapy

item.title: management of Barrett‚Äôs esophagitis
item.description: management of Barrett‚Äôs esophagitis PPI. W/o dysplasia: surveillance EGD q3‚Äì5y. Low-grade dysplasia: EGD q12mo; possible endoscopic eradication. High-grade dysplasia: endoscopic eradication; consider chemoprophylaxis w/ high-dose PPI & ASA (Lancet 2018;392:400).

item.description: Management of ICU patient-pulmonary hypertension Avoid tachyarrhythmias & overly aggressive volume resuscitation Caution w/ vasodilators if any L-sided dysfunction

item.title: Managing complications of Migraine
item.description: Managing complications of Migraine Identify comorbid conditions Select drugs and adiust their use according to comorbidities present Alleviate comborbidities if possible to improve outcome

item.title: Managing complications-acute kidney injury AKI
item.description: Managing complications-acute kidney injury (AKI) May take 1‚Äì3 wk to recover from ATN; anticipate volume overload, ‚Üë K, ‚Üë PO4, acidosis

item.title: Managing migraine in special populations
item.description: Managing migraine in special populations Older people Secondary headache, comorbidities and adverse events are all more likely Poor evidence base for all drugs in this age group Children and adolescents Be aware that presentation can differ from migraine in adults Parents and schools have important roles in the management of young children Bed rest alone can be sufficient Use ibuprofen for acute treatment and propranolol, amitriptyline or topiramate for prevention Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding Use paracetamol for acute treatment Avoid preventive treatment if possible Women with menstrual migraine Perimenstrual preventive therapy with long-acting NSAID or triptan

item.title: mechanisms of hypophosphatemia
item.description: mechanisms of hypophosphatemia Intracellular uptake of phosphate from the extracellular fluid #anki acute respiratory alkalosis: increased intracellular pH stimulates phosphofructokinase activity and glycolysis which leads to intracellular uptake of phosphate; hyperventilation (caused for example by sepsis, anxiety, diabetic ketoacidosis, or other underlying conditions) can precipitate intracellular shift of phosphate into cells; refeeding of malnourished patients; administration of insulin or glucose (which stimulates insulin secretion); hungry bone syndrome.

item.title: Mechanisms-Loop diuretics
item.description: Mechanisms-Loop diuretics inhib NaK2Cl cotransporter in thick ascending limb (ThAL, site of 25% Na reabsorp) ‚Üí ‚Üì medullary osmotic gradient & ‚Üì free H2O reabsorption via ADH

item.description: Meckel‚Äôs diverticulum Congenital intestinal pouch due to incomplete obliteration of vitelline duct. 2% of pop, w/in 2‚Ä≤ of IC valve, 2‚Ä≥ long, ‚ôÇ:‚ôÄ 2:1, can present as obscure GIB in adults.

item.title: Methotrexate
item.description: Methotrexate MTX is a folic acid antagonist. DNA synthesis is inhibited by inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase, which provides reduced folates for purine synthesis.

item.description: MI in absence of obstructive CAD Definition: MI but w/o coronary stenosis ‚â•50% in any major epicardial vessel More common in younger Pts, women, Black/Pacific race or Hispanic Advanced coronary imaging (eg, OCT) & cardiac MRI to exclude missed coronary obstruction, other causes of myocyte injury (eg, myocarditis), other causes of ‚Üë Tn (eg, PE) ~75% ischemic (ie, plaque disruption identified) and 25% alternative dx (eg, myocarditis)

item.description: Modification to initial antibiotic regimen based on site-specific evaluation of fever and neutropenia Vancomycin only if HoTN, PNA, clinically apparent catheter-related or soft-tissue infxn, gram ‚äï BCx, mucositis + on quinolone Ppx; d/c when BCx ‚äñ √ó 48 h for GPCs Mouth/esoph (ulcer, thrush): anaerobic (if necrotizing), anti-HSV and/or antifungal Rx Sinus/nasal: add vanc if periorbital cellulitis, ampho if concern for Aspergillus/Mucor Abd pain/diarrhea: PO vanc if concern for C.

item.title: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia MMVT
item.description: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (MMVT) All beats look similar; predominantly upward in V1 = RBBB-type vs. downward = LBBB-type In obviously structurally abnormal heart: prior MI (scar); CMP In apparently nl heart that is actually diseased: subtle HCM, infiltrative CMP, myocarditis, arrhythmogenic CMP (ACM): incomplete RBBB, Œµ wave (terminal notch in QRS) & TWI in V1‚ÄìV3 on resting ECG LBBB-type VT, dx w/ MRI (Lancet 2009;373:1289) In structurally normal heart w/ normal resting ECG & cardiac MRI: RVOT VT: LBBB-type VT or PVCs w/ inferior axis; typically ablate LVOT VT: RBBB-type VT or PVCs w/ superior axis; responds to verapamil

item.title: myocarditis
item.description: myocarditis Etiologies [[infectious myocarditis]] [[autoimmune myocarditis]] Clinical manifestations Highly variable, ranging from incidental dx based on labs/imaging to fulminant HF w/ shock Can present as ACS-like syndrome (chest pain, ECG Œîs, ‚Üë Tn), acute HF, arrhythmias Diagnostic studies and workup Echo: systolic dysfxn (typically global but can be regional); ¬± ‚Üë LV wall thickness due to edema; LV size may be small in fulminant and dilated in chronic; ¬± pericardial effusion Cardiac MRI: can show hyperemia, edema, and scar (JACC 2009;53:1475) Endomyocardial biopsy: useful in GCM & eosinophilic; ‚à¥ consider if rapidly progressive HF, high-grade AVB or sustained VT, suspected allergic rxn or eosinophilia Treatment Standard HF Rx if LV dysfxn (but do not start if e/o shock); temporary MCS as needed Immunosuppression: for GCM (high-dose steroids + CsA or tacrolimus ¬± AZA), collagen vascular disease, peripartum (?

item.title: Other diagnostic studies-syncope
item.description: Other diagnostic studies-syncope (consider based on results of H&P and ECG) Ambulatory ECG monitoring: if suspect arrhythmogenic syncope Holter monitoring (continuous ECG 24‚Äì72 h): useful if frequent events Event recorder (activated by Pt to record rhythm): limited role if LOC w/o prodrome External loop recorder (continuously saves rhythm, ‚à¥ can be activated after an event): useful for episodes (including w/o prodrome) likely to occur w/in 2‚Äì6 wks; can be coupled w/ mobile cardiac telemetry than can be auto-triggered for specific rhythms External patch recorder (1-lead recording; saves for 1‚Äì4 wks): Pt-activated or auto-triggered; more comfortable for Pts Implantable loop recorders (SC; can record 2‚Äì3 y; can be triggered): useful if episodes <1/mo; dx in 55% of cases; recommended for recurrent syncope w/o prodrome Echo: consider to r/o structural heart disease (eg, CMP [incl HCMP & ARVC], valvular disease [incl AS, MS, MVP], myxoma, amyloid, PHT, ¬± anomalous coronaries) ETT/CCTA/Cath: esp.

item.description: Pathogenesis epidemiology-clostridioides difficile infection Ingestion of C. diff spores ‚Üí colonization when colonic flora Œî‚Äôd by abx or chemo ‚Üí release of toxin A/B ‚Üí colonic mucosal necrosis & inflammation ‚Üí pseudomembranes

item.title: Pathogenesis etiology-chronic pancreatitis
item.description: Pathogenesis etiology-chronic pancreatitis (Gastro 2013;144:1292; JAMA 2019;322:2422) Often recurrent acute attacks ‚Üí inflam infiltrate ‚Üí fibrosis ‚Üí loss of exocrine & endocrine tissue.

item.title: pathogenesis of disseminated intravascular coagulation DIC
item.description: pathogenesis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) massive activation of coagulation that overwhelms control mechanisms Thrombosis in microvasculature ‚Üí ischemia + microangiopathic hemolytic anemia

item.title: pathogenesis of vasculitides
item.description: pathogenesis of vasculitides is not well understood, but potential pathophysiologic processes leading to vascular damage include immune complex deposition, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) (humoral mechanism), and T-lymphocyte response with granuloma formation (cell-mediated mechanism).

item.title: Pathogenesis-acute pancreatitis
item.description: Pathogenesis-acute pancreatitis Pancreatic duct and acinar injury via direct or indirect toxicity ‚Üí impaired secretion and premature activation of digestive enzymes ‚Üí autodigestion and acute inflammation

item.title: Pathogenesis-cholecystitis
item.description: Pathogenesis - [[cholecystitis]] Acute cholecystitis: stone impaction in cystic duct ‚Üí inflammation behind obstruction ‚Üí GB swelling ¬± secondary infection (50%) of biliary fluid

item.title: Pathogenesis-chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
item.description: Pathogenesis-chronic obstructive pulmonary disease Lancet 2017;389:1931 Cigarette smoke (centrilobular emphysema, affects 15‚Äì20% of smokers) Recurrent airway infections [[Œ±1-antitrypsin deficiency]] Low FEV1 in early adulthood associated with COPD (NEJM 2015;373:111)

item.title: Pathologic-Q-waves
item.description: Pathologic-Q-waves Q wave, Q Definition: ‚â•30 msec (‚â•20 msec V2‚ÄìV3) or >25% height of R wave in that QRS complex

item.title: Pathology pathogenesis esophageal cancer
item.description: Pathology pathogenesis esophageal cancer Squamous cell carcinoma Squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs) are usually located in the proximal or mid third of the esophagus.

item.title: Pathophysiology risk factors -aortic aneurysms
item.description: Pathophysiology risk factors -aortic aneurysms (JACC 2020:76:201 & 2021;78:201) Medial degen and/or ‚Üë wall stress; wall stress ‚àù [(‚àÜP √ó r) / (wall thickness)] (Laplace‚Äôs law) TAA: medial degeneration (muscle apoptosis, elastin fiber weakening); a/w CTD, aortitis AAA: long-standing HTN + athero/inflammation ‚Üí medial weakening Clinical risk factors: HTN, athero, smoking, age, ‚ôÇ, presence of other aortic dilation CTD (Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos type IV, Loeys-Dietz); congenital (bicuspid AoV, Turner‚Äôs) aortitis (Takayasu‚Äôs GCA, spondyloarthritis, IgG4); infection (eg, syphilis); FQ; trauma

item.title: Pathophysiology and microbiology of fever and neutropenia
item.description: Pathophysiology and microbiology of fever and neutropenia Predisposing factors: catheters, skin breakdown, GI mucositis, obstruction (lymphatics, biliary tract, GI, urinary tract), immune defect associated with malignancy Often thought due to seeding of bloodstream by GI flora, eg, GNRs (esp.

item.title: pathophysiology gastroesophageal reflux disease
item.description: pathophysiology gastroesophageal reflux disease (JAMA 2020;324:2536) ‚Üë acid exposure in esophagus, caused by ‚Üë transient LES relaxations. Worsened by ‚Üë intraabd pressure (eg, obesity, pregnancy), ‚Üì esophagogastric motility, hiatal hernia.

item.title: Pathophysiology of Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
item.description: Pathophysiology of Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis Type I: cryo precipitation in microcirculation ‚Üí hyperviscosity & vascular occlusion Types II/III: defective/insufficient immune complex (IC) clearance ‚Üí IC-mediated inflammation of blood vessels w/ complement activation ‚Üí vasculitis

item.title: Pathophysiology of diverticulitis
item.description: Pathophysiology of diverticulitis (NEJM 2007;357:2057; Gastro 2015;149:1944) Retention of undigested food and bacteria in diverticulum ‚Üí fecalith formation ‚Üí obstruction ‚Üí compromise of diverticulum‚Äôs blood supply, infection, microperforation Uncomplicated (75%): microperforation ‚Üí localized infection, LLQ pain, fever, ‚Üë WBC Complicated (25%): macroperf ‚Üí abscess, peritonitis, fistula (65% w/ bladder), obstrxn Clinical manifestations LLQ abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhea PEx ranges from LLQ tenderness ¬± palpable mass to peritoneal signs & septic shock Ddx includes IBD, infectious colitis, PID, tubal pregnancy, cystitis, colorectal cancer

item.title: Pathophysiology of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
item.description: Pathophysiology of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy LV outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) in ‚â•70%: narrowed tract 2¬∞ hypertrophied septum + systolic anterior motion (SAM) of ant.

item.title: Pathophysiology-Acetaminophen hepatotoxicity
item.description: Pathophysiology-Acetaminophen hepatotoxicity 90% of acetaminophen (N-acetyl-p-aminophenol, APAP) metab into nontoxic metab, but ~5% metab by CYP2E1 into NAPQI, a hepatotoxic metab detoxified by glutathione conjugation; APAP overdose (>10 g) depletes glutathione stores ‚Üí injury

item.title: Pathophysiology-ascites
item.description: Pathophysiology-ascites ( Hepatology 2021;74:1014) [[Pathogenesis of ascites and related complications of cirrhosis]] Portal HTN ‚Üí ‚Üë NO & prostaglandins ‚Üí splanchnic vasodilatation‚Üí ‚Üì effective arterial volume ‚Üí ‚Üë RAAS & ADH ‚Üí renal Na & H2O retention ‚Üí volume overload and ascites Portal hypertension leads to increased nitric oxide and prostaglandins, resulting in splanchnic vasodilation and decreased effective arterial volume.

item.title: Pathophysiology-constrictive pericarditis
item.description: Pathophysiology-constrictive pericarditis Adhesion of visceral and parietal pericardial layers ‚Üí rigid pericardium that limits diastolic filling of ventricles ‚Üí ‚Üë systemic venous pressures Venous return is limited only after early rapid filling phase; ‚à¥ rapid ‚Üì in RA pressure with atrial relaxation and opening of tricuspid valve and prominent x and y descents Kussmaul sign: JVP does not decrease with inspiration (‚Üë venous return with inspiration, but negative intrathoracic pressure not transmitted to heart because of rigid pericardium)

item.title: Pathophysiology-diabetic ketoacidosis
item.description: Pathophysiology-diabetic ketoacidosis (NEJM 2015;372:546) Occurs in T1D (and in ketosis-prone T2D); ‚Üë glucagon and ‚Üì insulin Hyperglycemia due to: ‚Üë gluconeogenesis, ‚Üë glycogenolysis, ‚Üì glucose uptake into cells Ketosis due to: insulin deficiency ‚Üí mobilization and oxidation of fatty acids, ‚Üë substrate for ketogenesis, ‚Üë ketogenic state of the liver, ‚Üì ketone clearance Explain by ChatGPT Acidosis due to: accumulation of [[ketone bodies]] Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a condition that can occur in people with type 1 diabetes (T1D) or ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes (T2D).

item.title: Pathophysiology-gastroesophageal reflux disease
item.description: Pathophysiology-gastroesophageal reflux disease Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is the second most common gastrointestinal diagnosis in the ambulatory setting and affects 18%‚Äì28% of people living in the North America.

item.title: Pathophysiology-Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias
item.description: Pathophysiology-Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias Ab binds heparin-PF4 ‚Üí immune complex binds to plt ‚Üí plt activation, further PF4 release ‚Üí plt aggregates removed from circulation ‚Üí thrombocytopenia; procoagulants released by plts and tissue factor released by endothelial cells damaged by HIT Abs ‚Üí prothrombotic state

item.title: Pathophysiology-hypernatremia
item.description: Pathophysiology-hypernatremia (Crit Care 2013;17:206; NEJM 2015;372:55) Deficit of water relative to sodium; by definition, all hypernatremic Pts are hypertonic

item.title: Pathophysiology-hyponatremia
item.description: Pathophysiology-hyponatremia (JASN 2008;19:1076; NEJM 2015;372:1349) Pathophysiology (JASN 2008;19:1076; NEJM 2015;372:1349) Excess H2O relative to Na, usually due to ‚Üë ADH ‚Üë ADH may be appropriate (eg, hypovolemia or hypervolemia with ‚Üì EAV) ‚Üë ADH may be inappropriate (SIADH) Rarely, ‚Üì ADH (appropriately suppressed), but kidneys unable to maintain nl [Na]serum at steady state, solute intake = solute excretion; urine output = solute excretion/Uosm nl dietary solute load ~750 mOsm/d, min Uosm = 50 mOsm/L, ‚à¥ UOP can be up to ~15 L ‚Üë H2O intake (1¬∞ polydipsia): ingestion of massive quantities (usually >15 L/d) of free H2O overwhelms diluting ability of kidney ‚Üí H2O retention ‚Üì solute intake (‚Äútea & toast‚Äù & beer potomania): ‚Üì‚Üì daily solute load ‚Üí insufficient solute to excrete H2O intake (eg, if only 250 mOsm/d, minimum Uosm = 50 mOsm/L ‚Üí excrete in ~5 L; if H2O ingestion exceeds this amount ‚Üí H2O retention)

item.title: Pathophysiology-metabolic-alkalosis
item.description: Pathophysiology-metabolic-alkalosis (CJASN 2020;15:1848) Saline-responsive etiologies require initiating event and maintenance phase Initiating event: net HCO3‚àí reabsorption (due to loss of volume, Cl-, and/or K+) or loss of H+ Loss of H+ (¬± Cl-) from GI tract, kidneys, or transcellular shift in hypokalemia Contraction alkalosis: loss of HCO3–poor fluid ‚Üí extracellular fluid ‚Äúcontracts‚Äù around fixed amount of HCO3- ‚Üí ‚Üë HCO3- concentration ÊµÅÂ§±ÊéâÈÖ∏Ê∂≤ Exogenous alkali: iatrogenic HCO3- (with renal impairment), [[milk-alkali syndrome]] Posthypercapnia: resp.

item.title: Pathophysiology-pericardial tamponade
item.description: Pathophysiology-pericardial tamponade ‚Üë intrapericardial pressure, compression of heart chambers, ‚Üì venous return ‚Üí ‚Üì CO Diastolic pressures ‚Üë & equalize in all cardiac chambers ‚Üí minimal flow of blood from RA to RV when TV opens ‚Üí blunted y descent ‚Üë ventricular interdependence ‚Üí pulsus paradoxus (pathologic exaggeration of nl physio) Inspiration ‚Üí ‚Üì intrapericardial & RA pressures ‚Üí ‚Üë venous return ‚Üí ‚Üë RV size ‚Üí septal shift to left.

item.description: Peritoneal dialysis-associated-Bacterial peritonitis cloudy fluid, abd pain, fever, nausea. Dx can be made with >50 PMNs. Culture most often GPC (50%) or GNR (15%).

item.description: Pharmacologic-stress-test Use if unable to exercise, low exercise tolerance, or recent MI. Se & Sp ‚âà exercise. Preferred if LBBB, WPW or V-paced, because higher prob of false ‚äï imaging with exercise
