item.description: Physical exam of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy Sustained PMI, S2 paradoxically split if severe outflow obstruction, ‚äï S4 (occ. palpable)

item.title: Physical Exam Secret
item.description: Physical Exam Secret Postural dizziness (severe enough to stop the test) or an increase in heart rate of at least 30 beats/minute has sensitivity of 97% and specificity of 96% for blood loss >630 mL.

item.title: Physical exam-acute bacterial meningitis
item.description: Physical exam-acute bacterial meningitis Brudzinski and Kernig signs of meningeal irritation appear unreliable for diagnosis or ruling out of meningitis.

item.title: Physical exam-bacterial endocarditis
item.description: Physical exam-bacterial endocarditis Cardiac murmur (85%), s/s of new HF (pulmonary edema, JVP elevation, edema) Skin/ocular changes (uncommon but highly specific) Janeway lesions (painless hemorrhagic macules on palms/ soles due to septic emboli) Osler‚Äôs nodes (painful nodules on pads of digits due to immune complex deposition) Splinter hemorrhages in fingernails or toenails Roth spots (retinal hemorrhages) MSK: point tenderness along spine, red/hot joints Neurologic deficits c/f embolic stroke; vertebral tenderness c/f osteo or epidural abscess Devices: evaluate CVCs, PM/ICD pocket, and sites of other hardware/ prosthetics

item.title: Physical exam-cirrhosis
item.description: Physical exam-cirrhosis Liver: initially enlarged, palpable (L lobe predom), firm; eventually shrunken, nodular Signs of liver failure: jaundice (bili >2.

item.title: Physical exam-constrictive pericarditis
item.description: Physical exam-constrictive pericarditis ‚Üë JVP with prominent y descent, ‚äï Kussmaul sign [Ddx: tricuspid stenosis, acute cor pulmonale, RV dysfxn (CMP, RV MI), SVC syndrome] Hepatosplenomegaly, ascites, peripheral edema.

item.title: Physical exam-mitral-stenosis
item.description: Physical exam-mitral-stenosis Low-pitched mid-diastolic rumble at apex w/ presystolic accentuation (if not in AF); best heard in L lat decubitus position during expiration, ‚Üë w/ exercise; severity proportional to duration (not intensity) of murmur; loud S 1 Opening snap (high-pitched early diastolic sound at apex) from fused leaflet tips; MVA proportional to S2‚ÄìOS interval (tighter valve ‚Üí ‚Üë LA pressure ‚Üí shorter interval) Loud S1 (unless MV calcified and immobile)

item.title: Physical exam-pericardial tamponade
item.description: Physical exam-pericardial tamponade Beck‚Äôs triad (present in minority of cases): distant heart sounds (28%), ‚Üë JVP (76%) w/ blunted y descent, hypotension (26%); ¬± pericardial friction rub (30%) Reflex tachycardia (77%), cool extremities Pulsus paradoxus (Se 82%, Sp 70%) = ‚Üì SBP ‚â•10 mmHg during inspiration ‚äï LR 3.

item.title: Physical exam-pericarditis and pericardial effusion
item.description: Physical exam-pericarditis and pericardial effusion Pericarditis: multiphasic friction rub best heard at LLSB w/ diaphragm of stethoscope. Notoriously variable and evanescent leathery sound w/ up to 3 components: atrial contraction, ventricular contraction, ventricular relaxation (NEJM 2012;367:e20).

item.title: Physical-exam-aortic-regurgitation
item.description: Physical-exam-aortic-regurgitation Early diastolic decrescendo murmur at LSB (RSB if dilated Ao root); ‚Üë w/ sitting forward, expir, handgrip; severity of AR ‚àù duration of murmur (except in acute and severe late); Austin Flint murmur: mid-to-late diastolic rumble at apex (AR jet interfering w/ mitral inflow) Wide pulse pressure due to ‚Üë stroke volume, hyper-dynamic pulse; pulse pressure narrows in late AR with ‚Üì LV fxn; bisferiens (twice-beating) arterial pulse PMI diffuse and laterally displaced; soft S1 (early closure of MV); ¬± S3 (‚â† ‚Üì EF but rather just volume overload in AR)

item.title: Physical-exam-aortic-stenosis
item.description: Physical-exam-aortic-stenosis Midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at RUSB, harsh, high-pitched, radiates to carotids, apex (holosystolic = Gallavardin effect), ‚Üë w/ passive leg raise, ‚Üì w/ standing & Valsalva.

item.title: Physical-exam-mitral-regurgitation
item.description: Physical-exam-mitral-regurgitation Early diastolic decrescendo murmur at LSB (RSB if dilated Ao root); ‚Üë w/ sitting forward, expir, handgrip; severity of AR ‚àù duration of murmur (except in acute and severe late); Austin Flint murmur: mid-to-late diastolic rumble at apex (AR jet interfering w/ mitral inflow) Wide pulse pressure due to ‚Üë stroke volume, hyper-dynamic pulse; pulse pressure narrows in late AR with ‚Üì LV fxn; bisferiens (twice-beating) arterial pulse PMI diffuse and laterally displaced; soft S1 (early closure of MV); ¬± S3 (‚â† ‚Üì EF but rather just volume overload in AR) Classic Eponymous Signs in Chronic AR Corrigan‚Äôs pulse ‚Äúwater hammer‚Äù pulse (ie, rapid rise/fall or distention/collapse) Hill‚Äôs sign (popliteal SBP ‚Äì brachial SBP) >60 mmHg Duroziez‚Äôs sign to-and-fro murmur heard over femoral artery w/ light compression Pistol shot sounds pistol shot sound heard over femoral artery Traube‚Äôs sound double sound heard over femoral artery when compressed distally de Musset‚Äôs sign head-bobbing with each heartbeat (low Se) M√ºller‚Äôs sign systolic pulsations of the uvula Quincke‚Äôs pulses subungual capillary pulsations (low Sp)

item.title: Pituitary apoplexy

item.title: Pituitary tumors
item.description: Pituitary tumors Pathophysiology: adenoma ‚Üí excess of trophic hormone (if tumor fxnal, but 30‚Äì40% not) and potentially deficiencies in other trophic hormones due to compression; cosecretion of PRL and growth hormone in 10% of prolactinomas Clinical manifestations: specific syndromes due to oversecretion of hormones (see below) ¬± non-specific mass effect: headache, visual Œîs, diplopia, cranial neuropathies Workup: MRI brain pituitary protocol, hormone levels, ¬± visual field testing if <10 mm, no mass effect, no hormone overproduction, can f/up in 12 mos

item.title: Pneumocystis jiroveci PCP pneumonia
item.description: Pneumocystis jiroveci (PCP) pneumonia fever, night sweats, dyspnea on exertion, dry (‚Äúdoorstop‚Äù) cough CXR w/ interstitial pattern, ‚Üì PaO2, ‚Üë A-a ‚àá, ‚Üë LDH, ‚äï PCP sputum stain, ‚äï Œ≤-glucan Rx if PaO2 >70: TMP-SMX 15‚Äì20 mg of TMP/kg divided tid, avg dose = DS 2 tabs PO tid Rx if PaO2 <70 or A-a gradient >35: prednisone before abx (40 mg PO bid; ‚Üì after 5 d) HIV ‚äï smokers much more likely to die from lung cancer than OI (JAMA 2017;177:1613)

item.title: Polyarteritis nodosa
item.description: Polyarteritis nodosa Usually middle-aged males. Hepatitis B seropositivity in 30% of patients. Fever, weight loss, malaise, headache. GI: abdominal pain, melena.

item.title: Polycystic kidney disease
item.description: Polycystic kidney disease (NEJM 2008;359:1477; 2017;377:1988) Mostly AD PKD1/PKD2 mutations ‚Üí renal cysts. PKD1 (85%) younger-onset ESRD. Rx: hydration, low-salt diet; tolvaptan reduces GFR decline.

item.title: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia PMVT
item.description: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (PMVT) QRS morphology changes from beat to beat Etiologies: ischemia; CMP; catecholaminergic torsades de pointes (TdP = ‚Äútwisting of the points,‚Äù PMVT + ‚Üë QT): ‚Üë QT acquired (meds, lytes, stroke, see ‚ÄúECG‚Äù) w/ risk ‚Üë w/ ‚Üì HR, freq PVCs (pause dependent) or congenital (K/Na channelopathies) w/ resting Tw abnl & TdP triggered by sympathetic stimulation (eg, exercise, emotion, sudden loud noises) (Lancet 2008;372:750) Brugada syndrome (Na channelopathy; JACC 2018;72:1046): ‚ôÇ > ‚ôÄ; pseudo-RBBB w/ STE in V1‚ÄìV3 (provoked w/ class IA or IC) on resting ECG

item.title: Polymyalgia rheumatica
item.description: Polymyalgia rheumatica (JAMA 2016;315:2442; Lancet 2017;390:1700) Prev 7/1000 of age ‚â•50. In 50% of GCA Pts; 15% of PMR Pts develop GCA.

item.title: Polyp or Tumor
item.description: Polyp or Tumor Typically slow ooze, p/w fatigue, weight loss, iron deficiency, anemia

item.title: polyps
item.description: polyps Pathophysiology & epidemiology (NEJM 2016;374:1065) Accumulation of mutations in colonic epithelial cell DNA affecting oncogenes & tumor suppressor genes ‚Üí tumor initiation (formation of adenoma; APC loss of fxn) ‚Üí tumor progression (adenoma ‚Üí carcinoma; K-ras gain of fxn, DCC, p53 loss of fxn) Risk factors: ‚Üë age, FHx (sporadic in 1¬∞ relatives, Lynch, FAP), IBD, ‚Üë dietary fat, central adiposity, ‚Üë EtOH, ‚Üì fiber, ‚Üë red meat, smoking, DM Protective factors: ‚Üë physical activity, ASA/NSAIDs, Ca2+ intake, HRT, ‚Üì BMI; possibly ‚Üë fiber, vitamin D, fish oil, statins, selenium Neoplastic polyps: adenomas (tubular, villous, tubulovillous dysplasia), sessile serrated adenomas/polyps (concern for interval CRC), carcinomas Non-neoplastic polyps: hyperplastic, juvenile, Peutz-Jeghers (can undergo malignant transformation), inflammatory [[CRC screening]]

item.title: polyuria
item.description: polyuria Definition and pathophysiology Polyuria defined as >3 L UOP per day Due to an osmotic or a water diuresis; almost always due to osmotic diuresis in inpatients Workup Perform a timed urine collection (6 h sufficient) and measure Uosm 24-h osmole excretion rate = 24-h UOP (actual or estimate) √ó Uosm 1000 mOsm/d ‚Üí osmotic diuresis; <800 mOsm/d ‚Üí water diuresis

item.title: Principles of Imaging in Vasculitides
item.description: Principles of Imaging in Vasculitides for large- and certain medium-vessel vasculitides, various imaging techniques can be useful magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) or computed tomography angiography (CTA) allow for the assessment of extensive vascular territories vessels not readily accessible for tissue biopsy ultrasound, particularly color-coded duplex sonography, is often used as first-line imaging in patients with suspected giant cell arteritis (GCA) small-vessel vasculitides difficult to directly visualize with imaging indirect signs can be detected; this may play a role in evaluating disease activity and extent of involvement Reference - Curr Rheumatol Rep 2020 Jun 19;22(8):34

item.description: Principles of treatment-asthma Education and avoidance of environmental triggers (Lancet 2015;386:1075); yearly flu shot Use quick-relief rescue medication as needed for all Pts

item.title: Principles-solitary pulmonary nodule
item.description: Principles-solitary pulmonary nodule Definition: single, well-defined, <3 cm, surrounded by nl lung, no LAN or pleural effusion Often ‚Äúincidentalomas,‚Äù esp with ‚Üë CT use, but may still be early, curable malignancy

item.description: Prinzmetal’s variant angina Coronary spasm ‚Üí transient STE usually w/o MI (but MI, AVB, VT can occur) Pts usually young, smokers ¬± other vasospastic disorders (eg, migraines, Raynaud‚Äôs) Angiography: nonobstructive CAD (spasm can be provoked during cath but rarely done) [[Treatment of Prinzmetals variant angina]] Cocaine-induced vasospasm: CCB, nitrates, ASA; ?

item.title: Prognosis-pulmonary hypertension
item.description: Prognosis-pulmonary hypertension Median survival after dx ~2.8 y; PAH (all etiologies): 2-y 66%, 5-y 48% (Chest 2004;126:78‚ÄìS) Poor prognostic factors: clinical evidence of RV failure, rapidly progressive sx, WHO (modified NYHA) class IV, 6MWT <300 m, peak VO2 <10.

item.title: Prognosis-syncope
item.description: Prognosis-syncope (Ann Emerg Med 1997;29:459; NEJM 2002;347:878) 22% overall recurrence rate if idiopathic, else 3% recurrence Cardiac syncope has poor prognosis (20‚Äì40% 1-y SCD rate); vasovagal good prognosis Unexplained syncope w/ 1.

item.title: Prognosis-ulcerative colitis
item.description: Prognosis-ulcerative colitis 50% in remission at any given time. Intermittent exacerbations in 90%; continual active disease in ~18%. Prox progression in 25% at 10 y.

item.title: Rationale PA catheter and tailored therapy
item.description: Rationale PA catheter and tailored therapy Cardiac output (CO) = SV √ó HR; optimize SV (and thereby CO) by manipulating preload/ LVEDV (w/ IVF, diuretics), contractility (w/ inotropes), & afterload (w/ vasodilators)

item.description: Raynaud phenomenon a problem that causes decreased blood flow to the fingers. In some cases, it also causes less blood flow to the ears, toes, nipples, knees, or nose.

item.description: Recommended First-Line Oral Direct-Acting Antiviral (DAA) Regimens Sofosbuvir & velpatasvir Genotypes 1‚Äì6, 12 weeks Rx Glecaprevir & pibrentasvir Gentotypes 1‚Äì6; 8 weeks Rx Simplified treatment: adults w/ HCV w/o cirrhosis or w/ compensated cirrhosis & no prior HCV treatment; cannot have HIV, HBsAg ‚äï, pregnancy, HCC, ESRD, or liver transplant; if decompensated or previously treated, refer to GI for assistance.

item.description: Refractory ascites seen in 5‚Äì10% of Pts; 2-y survival 25% Defined as [[diuretic-resistant]] if on 2-g Na diet w/ minimal weight loss on max diuretics, or diuretic-induced complications (AKI, Na <125, ‚Üë K, encephalopathy) Conflicting evid.

item.title: Renal tubular acidoses
item.description: Renal tubular acidoses (RTAs) (Adv Ther 2021;38:949) (Adv Ther 2021;38:949) Proximal (Type II): ‚Üì proximal reabsorption of HCO3 1¬∞ (Fanconi‚Äôs syndrome) = ‚Üì proximal reabsorption of HCO3, PO4, glc, amino acids Acquired: paraprotein (MM, amyloidosis), metals (Pb, Cd, Hg, Cu), ‚Üì vit D, PNH, renal Tx Meds: acetazolamide, aminoglycosides, ifosfamide, cisplatin, topiramate, tenofovir Distal (Type I): defective distal H+ secretion 1¬∞, autoimmune (Sj√∂gren‚Äôs, RA, SLE), hypercalciuria, meds (ampho, Li, ifosfamide); normally a/w ‚Üì K; if with ‚Üë K ‚Üí sickle cell, obstruction, renal transplant Hypoaldo (Type IV): hypoaldo ‚Üí ‚Üë K ‚Üí ‚Üì NH3 synthesis ‚Üí ‚Üì urine acid-carrying capacity ‚Üì renin: diabetic nephropathy, NSAIDs, chronic interstitial nephritis, calcineurin inh, HIV ‚Üì aldo production: 1¬∞ AI, ACEI/ARBs, heparin, severe illness, inherited (‚Üì 21-hydroxylase) ‚Üì response to aldosterone Meds: K-sparing diuretics, TMP-SMX, pentamidine, calcineurin inhibitors Tubulointerstitial disease: sickle cell, SLE, amyloid, DM

item.description: risk factor of delirium older aged >65 baseline cognitive dysfunction preexisting hearing and visual impairment, as well as indices for poor overall health, including baseline immobility, malnutrition, and underlying medical or neurologic illness.

item.description: Risk factors-acute aortic syndromes (Lancet 2015;385:800) Classic (in older Pts): HTN (h/o HTN in >70% of dissections); age (60s‚Äì70s), sex (~65% ‚ôÇ); smoking; ‚Üë lipids.

item.title: Risk Factors-bacterial endocarditis
item.description: Risk Factors-bacterial endocarditis Abnormal valve (JAMA 1997;277:1794; JACC 2018;72:2443) High risk: prior endocarditis, prosthetic valve or ring, some congenital heart disease (unrepaired cyanotic; shunt/conduit; prosthesis in past 6 mos), transplant heart, valvulopathy, VAD Medium risk previous rheumatic fever non-rheumatic valve disease (including MVP w/ MR or thickened leaflet), HCM bicuspid AoV Risk of bacteremia: IVDU indwelling venous catheters, hemodialysis, prosthetic material in heart (eg, pacemaker, ICD, graft), poor dentition

item.title: SCLC staging and treatment
item.description: SCLC staging and treatment SCLC usually disseminated at presentation; poor overall survival Can be very responsive to chemotherapy, but rapidly develop resistance Diagnosis: all have Rb & p53 mutations (Nature 2015;524:47); 90% w/ neuroendo markers Treatment: primarily chemo (platinum + etoposide); adding anti-[[PD-L1]] Ab [[atezolizumab]] ‚Üë survival (NEJM 2018;379:2220), as does concurrent thoracic RT in limited-stage disease Prophylactic cranial irradiation (PCI) controversial.

item.description: Scleroderma renal crisis (Nature Neph 2016;12:678) 5‚Äì20% diffuse cutaneous SSc w/ narrowing glomerular vessels. Sx: renal failure, severe HTN, encephalopathy.

item.description: transfusion-related acute lung injury : non-cardiogenic pulm. edema due to donor allo-Abs (from multiparous ‚ôÄ plasma) binding recipient WBCs, which then aggregate in pulmonary vasculature and release mediators causing ‚Üë capillary permeability.

item.title: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt TIPS
item.description: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) (Gastro 2017;152:157) ‚Üì ascites in 75%; ‚Üë CrCl, ‚Üë enceph, survival benefit over LVP remains controversial Contraindic: grade II enceph, CHF or pulm HTN, active infxn or biliary obstruction Complications: bleeding, fistula; stent thrombosis (1-y patency w/ coated stents ~80%); infxn (‚Äúendotipsitis‚Äù); new or ‚Üë enceph in 20‚Äì30% (Am J Gastro 2016;111:523), hemolysis Consider for liver transplant if above fail

item.title: Transudates
item.description: Transudates Congestive heart failure (40%): 80% bilateral, ¬± cardiomegaly on CXR occasionally exudative (especially after aggressive diuresis or if chronic) Constrictive pericarditis (knock on exam, calcification or thickening on imaging) Cirrhosis (‚Äúhepatic hydrothorax‚Äù): diaphragmatic pores allow passage of ascitic fluid often right-sided (¬≤‚àï¬≥) & massive (even witho marked ascites) Nephrotic syndrome: usually small, bilateral, asymptomatic (r/o PE b/c hypercoag) Other: PE (usually exudate), malignancy (lymphatic obstruction), myxedema, CAPD

item.title: treatment gastroesophageal reflux disease
item.description: treatment gastroesophageal reflux disease (World J Gastrointest Endosc 2018;10:175; Am J Gastro 2022;117:27) Lifestyle: avoid precipitants, lose weight, no eating 2 hrs before bed, exercise, √ò tobacco Medical: start low-dose PPI, uptitrate up to 40 mg bid; H2 blockers for intermittent sx Refractory (max dose ‚â•8 wks): confirm w/ pH testing on or off PPI, consider hernia repair If acidic or sx correlate w/ reflux episodes: surgical fundoplication (emerging Rx: LES sphincter augmentation w/ radiofrequency, implantable magnetic or electrical devices) If nl pH or no sx correlation = ‚Äúfxnal dyspepsia‚Äù (Gastro 2020;158:2286); Rx w/ TCA, SSRI

item.description: Treatment of Alchololic-associated hepatitis consider if MDF ‚â•32, MELD >18, or presence of encephalopathy Glucocorticoids (eg, methylprednisolone 32 mg/d or prednisolone 40 mg/d √ó 4 wk ‚Üí 4‚Äì6 wk taper) may ‚Üì 1-mo but not 6-mo mortality, a/w ‚Üë infection (NEJM 2015;372:1619, CD001511)

item.title: Treatment of Cushing‚Äôs syndrome
item.description: Treatment of Cushing‚Äôs syndrome (JCEM 2015;100:2807. J Intern Med 2019;286:526) Surgical: * resection of pituitary adenoma, adrenal tumor or ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor, or bilateral surgical adrenalectomy if unable to control source of ACTH Medical: [[ketoconazole]] [[metyrapone]] [[osilodrostat]] [[cabergoline]] [[pasireotide]] mitotane to ‚Üì cortisol, and/or mifepristone to block cortisol action at glucocorticoid receptor frequently used as bridge to surgery or when surgery contraindicated Radiation: can do pituitary XRT, but not effective immediately (takes 6 mo to 2 y) Glucocorticoid replacement therapy √ó 6‚Äì36 mo after TSS (lifelong glucocorticoid + mineralocorticoid replacement if medical or surgical adrenalectomy)

item.title: Treatment of Hemochromatosis
item.description: Treatment of Hemochromatosis phlebotomy (250 mL = 1 unit, ~250 mg of Fe) qwk until Fe sat <50% & ferritin 50‚Äì100 ¬µg/L, then q3‚Äì4mo; PPI ‚Üì intestinal Fe absorption & may ‚Üì need for phlebotomy; avoid vit C & uncooked seafood; deferoxamine if phleb.

item.title: Treatment of HIT
item.description: Treatment of HIT (NEJM 2015;373:252; Blood Adv 2018;2:3360) Discontinue heparin (incl. flushes, LMWH Ppx, heparin lines). Avoid plts (anecdotal link w/ thrombosis); if given warfarin, give vit K to reverse, prevent warfarin skin necrosis.

item.title: Treatment of Hyperkalemia-hyperkalemia
item.description: Treatment of Hyperkalemia-hyperkalemia [[Ca gluconate Ca chloride]] 1‚Äì2 amps IV onset <3 min with Transient effect (30‚Äì60 min) Stabilizes cell membrane CaCl contains more calcium and is typically reserved for codes (‚Üë risk of tissue necrosis) or via central line

item.title: Treatment of Hypervolemic hyponatremia

item.title: Treatment of Hypovolemic hyponatremia
item.description: Treatment of Hypovolemic hyponatremia volume repletion with isotonic 0.9% saline at a slow rate. Once volume replete ‚Üí stimulus for ADH removed (w/ very short ADH t¬Ω) ‚Üí kidneys excrete free H2O ‚Üí serum Na will correct rapidly (D5W ¬± dDAVP if overcorrection)

item.title: Treatment of latent TB
item.description: Treatment of latent TB If screening test ‚äï and no risk factors, confirm prior to treatment; if ‚äï w/ risk factors, proceed to treatment (CID 2017;64:11).

item.title: Treatment of LDL-C
item.description: Treatment of LDL-C Statins: every 1 mmol (39 mg/dL) ‚Üì LDL-C ‚Üí 22% ‚Üì major vascular events (CV death, MI, stroke, revasc) in individuals w/ & w/o CAD (Lancet 2010;376:1670) Ezetimibe: ‚Üì major vascular events incl MI & stroke when added to statin post-ACS, w/ magnitude of benefit consistent w/ LDL-statin relationship (IMPROVE-IT, NEJM 2015;372:2387) PCSK9 inhibitors: ~60% ‚Üì LDL-C on top of statin, as monoRx, and in FH (EHJ 2014;35:2249); ‚Üì CV outcomes (NEJM 2017;376:1713 & 2018;379:2097) In homozygous FH: apheresis; evinacumab (ANGPTL3 inhib) ‚Üì LDL-C by ~50% (NEJM 2020;383:711)

item.title: Treatment of Migraine
item.description: Treatment of Migraine Abortive Rx: 5-HT1 agonists (triptans) effective if given early in migraine attack; Abortive: The goal of abortive treatment is to stop a migraine once it starts.

item.description: Treatment of Thyroid storm Œ≤-blocker, PTU or methimazole, iopanoic acid or iodide (for [[Wolff-Chaikoff effect]]) >1 h after PTU, ¬± steroids (‚Üì T4 ‚Üí T3)

item.description: Treatment of UTIs Scenario Empiric Treatment Guidelines (narrow based on UCx) Asymptomatic bacteruria Do not treat. Exceptions: pregnant women, renal transplant, prophylaxis prior to invasive urologic procedures (CID 2019;68:1611).

item.description: Treatment peptic ulcer disease (Lancet 2016;388:2355; Gastro 2016;151:51; Gut 2017;66:6; AJG 2017;112:212) If H. pylori ‚äï ‚Üí eradicate (‚Äútest and treat‚Äù); if ‚äñ ‚Üí gastric acid suppression w/ PPI 1st line: Quad.

item.title: Treatment prevention-herpes zoster
item.description: Treatment prevention-herpes zoster Uncomplicated: acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir x 7 d; initiate w/in 72 h of onset for greatest benefit; consider after 72 h if new lesions present; minimal benefit after crusting Superimposed bacterial cellulitis is common; if suspected, treat with appropriate antibiotics Disseminated/immunosupp.

item.title: Treatment-accessory pathways wolff-parkinson-white
item.description: Treatment-accessory pathways (wolff-parkinson-white) (Heart Rhythm 2012;9:1006, Circ 2014;130:e199 & 2016;133:e506) AVRT (orthodromic): vagal, Œ≤B, CCB; care w/ adenosine (can precip AF); have defib ready AF/AFL w/ conduction down accessory pathway: need to Rx arrhythmia and ‚Üë pathway refractoriness.

item.title: Treatment-Acetaminophen hepatotoxicity
item.description: Treatment-Acetaminophen hepatotoxicity NG lavage, activated charcoal if w/in 4 h. Consider early transfer to transplant ctr N-acetylcysteine: administer up to 72 h after ingestion, if time of ingestion unknown or chronic ingestion >4g/d; low threshold to start NAC w/ low or undetectable APAP levels

item.title: Treatment-acute aortic syndromes
item.description: Treatment-acute aortic syndromes (Circ 2010;121:1544; EHJ 2018;39:739; JACC 2019;74:1494 & 2020;76:1703) ‚Üì dP/dt targeting HR <60 & central BP <120 (or lowest that preserves perfusion; r/o pseudohypotension, eg, arm BP ‚Üì due to subclavian dissection; use highest BP reading) First IV Œ≤B (eg, esmolol, labetalol) to blunt reflex ‚Üë HR & inotropy in response to vasodilators; verapamil/diltiazem if Œ≤B contraindic; then ‚Üì SBP w/ IV vasodilators (eg, nitroprusside) If HoTN: urgent surgical consult, IVF to achieve euvolemia, pressors to keep MAP 60-65 mmHg; r/o complication (eg, tamponade, contained rupture, severe AI) Proximal: surgery considered in all acute and in chronic if c/b progression, AI or aneurysm Distal: med Rx unless complication (see below) or favorable TEVAR anatomy w/ high-risk imaging features (JACC 2019;74:1494); pre-emptive TEVAR may ‚Üì late complic.

item.title: Treatment-acute mesenteric ischemia
item.description: Treatment-acute mesenteric ischemia IVF, NPO, optimize hemodynamics (minimize pressors), broad-spectrum abx, anticoagulation w/ heparin ¬± tPA (for occlusive disease), IV papaverine (vasodilator; for non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia)

item.title: Treatment-acute pancreatitis
item.description: Treatment-acute pancreatitis Fluid resusc.: aggressive in 1st 24 hrs, even if mild. 20 mL/kg IVB ‚Üí 3 mL/kg/hr. Goal ‚Üì BUN & Hct over 12‚Äì24 h.

item.description: Treatment-acute respiratory distress syndrome [[methylprednisolone]]

item.title: Treatment-anaphylaxis
item.description: Treatment-anaphylaxis Epi: 0.5 mg IM (0.5 mL of 1 mg/mL solution) q5‚Äì15min as needed. For those who do not respond, IV infusion starting at 0.

item.title: Treatment-Anemia of chronic inflammation
item.description: Treatment-Anemia of chronic inflammation treat underlying disease ¬± iron and/or erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA; eg, Epo). Iron if ferritin <100 or Fe/TIBC <20%.

item.title: Treatment-aortic aneurysms
item.description: Treatment-aortic aneurysms (Circ 2010;121:e266 & 2016;133:680; JACC 2020;76:201; NEJM 2021;385:1690) Goal is to prevent rupture (50% mortality prior to hospital) by modifying risk factors Risk factor modification: smoking cessation; statins to achieve LDL-C <70 mg/dL BP control (goal SBP 100‚Äì120): Œ≤B (‚Üì dP/dt) ‚Üì aneurysm growth; ACEI a/w ‚Üì rupture risk (Lancet 2006;368:659); ARB may ‚Üì rate of aortic root growth in Marfan (NEJM 2008;358:2787) Mod CV exercise OK, no burst activity requiring Valsalva maneuvers (eg, heavy lifting) Indications for intervention (individualized based on FHx, body size, sex, anatomy) TAA: sxs; ascending Ao ‚â•5.

item.title: Treatment-aortic-regurgitation
item.description: Treatment-aortic-regurgitation Acute decompensation (consider endocarditis as possible acute precipitant): surgery usually urgently needed for acute severe AR, which is poorly tolerated by LV IV afterload reduction (nitroprusside) and inotropic support (dobutamine) ¬± chronotropic support (‚Üë HR ‚Üí ‚Üì diastole ‚Üí ‚Üì time for regurgitation) pure vasoconstrictors and IABP contraindicated In chronic AR, management decisions based on LV size and fxn (and before sx occur); low diastolic BP and high resting HR associated with mortality (JACC 2020;75:29) Surgery (AVR, replacement or repair if possible): Severe and sx (if equivocal, consider stress test) Asx and either EF ‚â§55%, LV dilation [LVESD >50 mm or LVESDi (indexed to BSA) ‚â• 25 mm/m2 (JACC 2019;73:1741)], or undergoing cardiac surg Transcatheter AoV implantation (TAVI) being explored (JACC 2013;61:1577 & 2017;70:2752) Medical therapy: vasodilators (nifedipine, ACEI/ARB, hydralazine) if severe AR w/ sx or LV dysfxn & not operative candidate or to improve hemodynamics before AVR.

item.title: Treatment-ascites
item.description: Treatment-ascites ‚Üì Na intake (1‚Äì2 g/d); restrict intake of free water if Na <125 Diuretics: goal diurese ~1 L/d.

item.title: Treatment-bacterial endocarditis
item.description: Treatment-bacterial endocarditis Empiric NVE or PVE >12 mos post-op: vanc + CTX PVE <12 mos post op: vanc + CTX ¬± gentamicin (if OK renal fxn)

item.title: Treatment-bronchiectasis
item.description: Treatment-bronchiectasis Acute exacerbations: antibiotics directed against prior pathogens; if no prior Cx data ‚Üí FQ Chronic mgmt: treat underlying condition, chest PT, inhaled hypertonic saline, bronchodil.

item.title: Treatment-Candida species
item.description: Treatment-Candida species Mucocutaneous Clotrimazole, nystatin, fluconazole, itraconazole Candiduria (if pyuria or sx of infxn) Fluconazole or intravesical ampho if severe infxn, immunosupp.

item.title: Treatment-cholangitis
item.description: Treatment-cholangitis Antibiotics (broad spectrum) to cover common bile pathogens (see above) ampicillin + gentamicin (or levofloxacin) ¬± MNZ (if severe); carbapenems; pip/tazo

item.title: Treatment-cholelithiasis
item.description: Treatment-cholelithiasis (Am Fam Physician 2014;89:795; J Hepatol 2016;65:146) Cholecystectomy (CCY), usually laparoscopic, if symptomatic (earlier is better) CCY in asx Pts if: GB calcification (‚Üë risk of cancer), GB polyps >10 mm, stones >3 cm; Pts undergoing bariatric surgery, cardiac Tx candidates, hemolytic anemia (sickle cell)

item.title: Treatment-chronic pancreatitis
item.description: Treatment-chronic pancreatitis (JAMA 2019;322:2422; Lancet 2020;396:499) Pancreatic enzyme replacement (may ‚Üì pain by reducing CCK). Rx routine vitamin D & Ca.

item.title: Treatment-cystic fibrosis
item.description: Treatment-cystic fibrosis Lancet 2021;397:2195) Acute exacerbations: may be assoc w/ persistent drop in FEV1 (AJRCCM 2010;182:627); continue aggressive airway clearance, target abx based on sputum cx (incl double coverage for PsA); common pathogens include PsA, S.

item.title: Treatment-diabetic foot infections
item.description: Treatment-diabetic foot infections (CID 2012;54:e132) Mild infxn: oral abx. Target GPCs (diclox, cephalexin, or amox/clav); use TMP-SMX or doxy for MRSA.

item.title: Treatment-diverticulitis
item.description: Treatment-diverticulitis (JAMA 2017;318:291; NEJM 2018;379:1635; Gastro 2021;160:906) Mild: outPt Rx indicated if Pt has few comorbidities and can tolerate POs PO abx: (MNZ + FQ) or amox/clav for 7 d; liquid diet until clinical improvement No abx is noninferior to abx in uncomplicated diverti (Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2021;19:503)

item.title: Treatment-epidural abscess
item.description: Treatment-epidural abscess Antibiotics (typically MRSA and gram-negative coverage initially then narrowed based on culture data) ¬± surgery (decompressive laminectomy and debridement) for failure to improve on medical Rx.

item.title: Treatment-fever of unknown origin
item.description: Treatment-fever of unknown origin Empiric abx not indicated (unless Pt neutropenic or critically ill) Empiric glucocorticoids not indicated unless strong suspicion for specific rheumatologic dx Stop unnecessary meds (only 20% with a med cause have eos or rash) Up to 30% of cases remain undiagnosed, most spontaneously defervesce (wks to mos)

item.title: Treatment-glomerulonephritis
item.description: Treatment-glomerulonephritis (AJKD 2020;75:124 & 2020;76:265) If acute GN/RPGN suspected, give 500‚Äì1000 mg methylpred. IV qd √ó 3d ASAP while awaiting bx results.

item.title: Treatment-hemoptysis
item.description: Treatment-hemoptysis Death is from [[asphyxiation]]Á™íÊÅØ not exsanguination; maintain gas exchange, reverse coagulopathy and Rx underlying condition; cough suppressant may ‚Üë risk of asphyxiation Inhaled tranexamic acid promising (Chest 2018;154:1379) nebulized TA (500 mg tid) Massive hemoptysis: put bleeding side dependent; selectively intubate nl lung if needed Angiography: Dx & Rx (vascular occlusion balloons or selective embol of bronchial art) Rigid bronch: allows more options (electrocautery, laser) than flexible bronch Surgical resection

item.title: Treatment-Hepatorenal syndrome HRS
item.description: Treatment-Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) if critically ill ‚Üí vasopressor (eg, norepinephrine or vasopressin) + albumin (1 g/kg, max 100 g, bolus daily) to ‚Üë MAP 10 mmHg.

item.title: Treatment-hyperaldosteronism
item.description: Treatment-hyperaldosteronism (SCNA 2014;94:643) Adenoma ‚Üí adrenalectomy vs. medical Rx w/ spironolactone or eplerenone Hyperplasia ‚Üí spironolactone or eplerenone; GRA ‚Üí glucocorticoids ¬± spironolactone Carcinoma ‚Üí adrenalectomy

item.title: Treatment-hypernatremia
item.description: Treatment-hypernatremia Restore access to H2O or supply daily requirement of H2O (‚â•1 L/d) [[Replace free H2O deficit]]

item.title: Treatment-hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state
item.description: Treatment-hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state Rule-out possible precipitants; ~15% mortality due to precipitating factors Aggressive hydration: initially NS, then ¬Ω NS, average fluid loss up to 8‚Äì10 L Insulin (eg, 10 U IV followed by 0.

item.title: Treatment-hypertension
item.description: Treatment-hypertension Every ‚Üì 5 mmHg ‚Üí ~10% ‚Üì ischemic heart disease, stroke, and HF (Lancet 2021;397:1625) Lifestyle modifications as Treatment-hypertension (each may ‚Üì SBP ~5 mmHg) weight loss: goal BMI 18.

item.title: Treatment-hypertensive crises
item.description: Treatment-hypertensive crises (Circ 2018;138:e426) AoD, eclampsia/severe preeclampsia, pheo: target SBP <140 (<120 for AoD) in 1 hour Emerg w/o above: ‚Üì BP by ~25% in 1 h; to 160/100‚Äì110 over next 2‚Äì6 h, then nl over 1‚Äì2 d Acute ischemic stroke (w/in 72 hr from sx onset): <185/110 before lysis initiated, o/w target <220/120 (same SBP goal for ICH) Watch UOP, Cr, mental status: may indicate a lower BP is not tolerated [[IV Drugs for Hypertensive Crises]] HTN urgency: goal to return to normal BP over hrs to days.

item.title: Treatment-hyperthyroidism
item.description: Treatment-hyperthyroidism Œ≤-blockers: control tachycardia (propranolol also ‚Üì T4 ‚Üí T3 conversion) Graves‚Äô disease: either antithyroid drugs or radioactive iodine (NEJM 2016;375:1552) methimazole: 60% chance of recurrence after 1 y; side effects include pruritus, rash, arthralgia, fever, N/V and agranulocytosis in 0.

item.title: Treatment-hypocalcemia
item.description: Treatment-hypocalcemia also treat concomitant vitamin D deficiency; Endocrine 2020;69:485 ‰πüË¶ÅÊ≤ªÁôÇÁ∂≠ÁîüÁ¥† D Áº∫‰πèÁóá Severely symptomatic: Ca gluconate (1‚Äì2 g IV over 20 min) + oral Ca + calcitriol (but takes hrs to work) ¬± Mg (50‚Äì100 mEq/d); 10% CaCl2 in codes or via CVL

item.title: Treatment-hypokalemia
item.description: Treatment-hypokalemia (JAMA 2000;160:2429) If true potassium deficit: potassium repletion (‚Üì 1 mEq/L ‚âà 200 mEq total body loss) Dosage: 40 mEq PO q4h, 10 mEq/h (IV), 20 mEq/h (central line), 40 mEq in 1 L IVF

item.title: Treatment-hypopituitary syndromes
item.description: Treatment-hypopituitary syndromes Replace deficient target gland hormones Most important deficiencies to recognize and treat in inpatients are adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism; if both present, treat with glucocorticoids first, then replace thyroid hormone so as not to precipitate adrenal crisis

item.title: Treatment-mitral-regurgitation
item.description: Treatment-mitral-regurgitation Treatment (Lancet 2016;387:1312; Circ 2021;143:e72) Acute decompensation (consider endocarditis as possible acute precipitant): surgery usually urgently needed for acute severe AR, which is poorly tolerated by LV IV afterload reduction (nitroprusside) and inotropic support (dobutamine) ¬± chronotropic support (‚Üë HR ‚Üí ‚Üì diastole ‚Üí ‚Üì time for regurgitation) pure vasoconstrictors and IABP contraindicated In chronic AR, management decisions based on LV size and fxn (and before sx occur); low diastolic BP and high resting HR associated with mortality (JACC 2020;75:29) Surgery (AVR, replacement or repair if possible): Severe and sx (if equivocal, consider stress test) Asx and either EF ‚â§55%, LV dilation [LVESD >50 mm or LVESDi (indexed to BSA) ‚â• 25 mm/m2 (JACC 2019;73:1741)], or undergoing cardiac surg Transcatheter AoV implantation (TAVI) being explored (JACC 2013;61:1577 & 2017;70:2752) Medical therapy: vasodilators (nifedipine, ACEI/ARB, hydralazine) if severe AR w/ sx or LV dysfxn & not operative candidate or to improve hemodynamics before AVR.

item.title: Treatment-mitral-stenosis
item.description: Treatment-mitral-stenosis Medical: Na restriction, cautious diuresis, Œ≤B, AF control, sx-limited physical stress Antibiotic Ppx recommended if h/o RHD w/ valvular disease for 10 y or until age 40 Anticoag w/ warfarin (not DOAC) if: AF; prior embolism; LA clot Mechanical intervention indicated if sx severe MS; reasonable if asx severe MS but PASP >50 mmHg and morphology favorable for PMBC; consider PMBC if non-severe MS but exertional sx and hemodyn signif w/ exercise, or if asx severe MS and new-onset AF Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC): preferred Rx if RHD; ‚âà MVR if valvuloplasty score <8, √ò if mod-severe MR or LA clot Surgical (MV repair if possible, o/w replacement) if PMBC contraindicated Calcific MS: surgical MVR if severe & highly sx; use of transcatheter aortic prosthesis experimental and w/ high rate of complications (Circ CVI 2020;13:e008425) Pregnancy: if NYHA class III/IV ‚Üí PMBC, o/w medical Rx w/ low-dose diuretic & Œ≤B

item.title: Treatment-nephrotic syndrome
item.description: Treatment-nephrotic syndrome (NEJM 2013;368:10) General: protein suppl.; diuretics for edema; treat hyperlipidemia, Na restriction (<2 g/d) ACEI or ARB: ‚Üì proteinuria ‚Üí slow nonimmunologic progression of renal disease

item.title: Treatment-Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease NAFLD
item.description: Treatment-Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) wt loss (‚â•10%), exercise, DM control, liraglutide (Lancet 2016;387:679), statins (Metabolism 2017;71:17), vit E in Pts w/o DM (Hepatol 2018;67:328), bariatric surgery (World J Hepatol 2019;11:138).

item.title: Treatment-of-hyponatremia
item.description: Treatment-of-hyponatremia NEJM 2015;372:55; JASN 2017;28:1340; CJASN 2018;13:641 & 984) [[Approach to treatment-of-hyponatremia]]: Frequent lab draws and IVF rate adjustments are cornerstones of treatment [[Rapid correction of Treatment-of-hyponatremia]]: [[Effect of IV fluids-treatment-of-hyponatremia]] [[Effect of 1 L infusion in 70-kg male]] ÂàÜÈ°ûÔºö [[Treatment of Hypovolemic hyponatremia]] [[Treatment of SIADH]] [[Treatment of Hypervolemic hyponatremia]]

item.title: Treatment-osteomyelitis
item.description: Treatment-osteomyelitis Antibiotics: based on cx data. If clinically stable, consider holding antibiotics until bone bx obtained. Duration depends on Rx strategy/goals of Rx management (eg, 6 wks for vertebral osteo; Lancet 2015;385:875).

item.title: Treatment-Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
item.description: Treatment-Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria supportive care (iron, folate, transfusions); consider anticoagulation. Allogeneic HSCT for hypoplasia or severe thrombosis. Pegcetacoplan (binds C3, prevents complement cascade activation) superior to eculizumab (Ab inactivates terminal complement C5s) in ‚Üì hemolysis & stabilizing Hb levels (NEJM 2021;384:1028).

item.title: Treatment-pericardial tamponade
item.description: Treatment-pericardial tamponade Volume (but be careful b/c overfilling can worsen tamponade) and ‚äï inotropes (avoid Œ≤B) Avoid vasoconstrictors b/c will ‚Üì stroke volume & potentially ‚Üì HR Avoid positive pressure ventilation b/c it can further impair cardiac filling (Circ 2006;113:1622) Pericardiocentesis (except if due to aortic/myocardial rupture, for which emergent surgery is treatment of choice; if too unstable, consider small pericardiocentesis to prevent PEA) Surgical drainage considered if fluid rapidly reaccumulates, loculated, or hemorrhagic

item.title: Treatment-pleural effusion
item.description: Treatment-pleural effusion Symptomatic effusion: therapeutic thoracentesis, treat underlying disease process Parapneumonic effusion (Chest 2000;118:1158) uncomplicated ‚Üí antibiotics for pneumonia

item.title: Treatment-pneumonia
item.description: Treatment-pneumonia CAP (outPt) Amoxicillin, azithro, or doxy (avoid latter two if >25% resistance locally) CAP (ward) [3rd-gen ceph + azithro] or levoflox; omadacycline ‚âà FQ (NEJM 2019;380:517)

item.title: Treatment-polyuria
item.description: Treatment-polyuria 1¬∞ polydipsia: treat psychiatric illness, check meds, restrict access to free H2O Osmotic diuresis: address underlying cause, replace free H 2O deficit (see ‚ÄúHypernatremia‚Äù for formula to calculate) and ongoing losses Treatment of Diabetes insipidus [[treatment of Central DI]]: [[desmopressin]] (dDAVP, 1st line), low Na/protein diet + HCTZ, chlorpropamide Nephrogenic DI: treat underlying cause if possible; Na restriction + HCTZ (mild volume depletion ‚Üí ‚Üì delivery of filtrate for free H2O absorption), consider amiloride for Li- induced DI (Kid Int 2009;76:44), indomethacin (NEJM 1991;324:850) or trial desmopression Pregnancy-induced DI: due to vasopressinase from placenta, ‚à¥ Rx w/ dDAVP

item.title: Treatment-Portal vein thrombosis PVT
item.description: Treatment-Portal vein thrombosis (PVT) Treatment: Acute: If noncirrhotic, LMWH ‚Üí warfarin or DOAC √ó 6 mo, or indefinitely if irreversible cause.

item.title: Treatment-Primary sclerosing cholangitis PSC
item.description: Treatment-Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) supportive care, fat-soluble vitamins; no meds have improved survival UDCA may ‚Üì Aœï & improve Sx, but unclear if beneficial

item.title: Treatment-pulmonary hypertension
item.description: Treatment-pulmonary hypertension Principles: 1) prevent & reverse vasoactive substance imbalance and vascular remodeling 2) prevent RV failure: ‚Üì wall stress (‚Üì PVR, PAP, RV diam); ensure adeq systemic DBP Supportive Oxygen: maintain SaO2 >90‚Äì92% (reduces vasoconstriction) Diuretics: ‚Üì RV wall stress and relieve RHF sx; gentle b/c RV is preload dependent Anticoag: not routinely used; ‚Üì VTE risk of RHF; ?

item.title: Treatment-Pure red cell aplasia
item.description: Treatment-Pure red cell aplasia thymectomy if thymus enlarged; IVIg if parvovirus and immunosuppressed (Clin Infect Dis 2013;56:968); immunosuppression/chemoRx if CLL or idiopathic; supportive care w/ PRBC transfusions; ?

item.title: Treatment-sexually transmitted infections
item.description: Treatment-sexually transmitted infections (MMWR 2021;70:1; JAMA 2022;327:161) Syphilis 1¬∞/2¬∞/early latent: PCN G benzathine 2.4 mil U IM √ó 1 3¬∞/late latent: PCN G 2.

item.title: Treatment-skin and soft tissue infections
item.description: Treatment-skin and soft tissue infections (CID 2014;60:169) Urgent surgical exploration with debridement of necrotic tissue and ID consultation Empiric antibiotics: [pip/tazo or ceftriaxone + metronidazole or carbapenem] + [vanco or linezolid].

item.title: Treatment-syncope
item.description: Treatment-syncope (JACC 2017;70:620 & 2019;74:2410; EHJ 2018;39:1883) Arrhythmia, cardiac mechanical or neurologic syncope: treat underlying disorder, ? ICD if Brugada pattern, sarcoid, ARVC, early repol + syncope Vasovagal: avoidance of triggers; physical counterpressure; consider ‚Üë Na & fluid intake, fludrocortisone or midodrine (JACC 2016;68:1; Ann Intern Med 2021;174:1349); SSRI; ?

item.title: Treatment-Vitamin B12 deficiency
item.description: Treatment-Vitamin B12 deficiency 1 mg B12 IM qd √ó 7 d ‚Üí q wk √ó 4‚Äì8 wk ‚Üí q month for life

item.title: Treatment-Wilson disease
item.description: Treatment-Wilson disease chelation w/ D-penicillamine (supplement B6 as D-pen inactivates); alternative is trientine (‚Üì toxicity w/ ‚âà efficacy, but $$), ammonium or bis-choline tetrathiomolybdate (investigational) may ‚Üì neurologic deterioration compared to trientine.

item.title: Triage-pneumonia
item.description: Triage-pneumonia qSOFA predicts poor outcomes, prolonged ICU stay, and in-hospital mortality if >2 of 3: RR>22, AMS, SBP<100 (JAMA 2016; 315:801)

item.title: tricuspid-regurgitation
item.description: tricuspid-regurgitation TRICUSPID REGURGITATION (Circ 2014;129:2440; Lancet 2016;388:2431) Fxnl etiol (90%): RV dilation, PHT (may be 2¬∞ to L-sided dis.), large L ‚Üí R shunts 1¬∞ etiol: myxomatous, IE, pacemaker leads, RHD, CTD, XRT, Ebstein‚Äôs, carcinoid, tumors Holosystolic murmur, 3rd/4th ICS, ‚Üë w/ insp (Carvallo‚Äôs sign); S3; prominent cv wave in JVP Consider repair/replacement in severe TR (eg, ERO ‚â•0.

item.title: Tricyclic antidepressants-toxicology
item.description: Tricyclic antidepressants-toxicology Hypotension, seizures, arrhythmia, ‚Üë QRS, ‚Üë QT IVF resuscitation, IV sodium bicarbonate, vasopressors

item.title: Troponin
item.description: Troponin 99th %ile w/ rise and/or fall in approp. setting is dx of AMI (Circ 2018;138:e618) [[Fourth Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction (2018)]]

item.title: Tuberculin skin test
item.description: Tuberculin skin test (TST/ PPD): inject purified protein intradermally, examine for wheal 48‚Äì72 hrs later. Interpret based on max diameter of induration, not erythema.

item.title: Tubulointerstitial proteinuria
item.description: Tubulointerstitial proteinuria (usually <1‚Äì2 g/d) ‚Üì reabsorption of freely filtered proteins ‚Üí lose globulins Etiologies ATN; AIN [[Fanconi‚Äôs syndrome]]

item.title: type 1 MI
item.description: type 1 MI includes detection of a rise and/or fall of cTn with at least one value above the 99th percentile and with at least one of the following: Symptoms of acute myocardial ischemia; New ischemic electrocardiographic (ECG) changes; Development of pathological Q waves; Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality in a pattern consistent with an ischemic etiology; Identification of a coronary thrombus by angiography including intracoronary imaging or by autopsy.

item.title: type 2 MI
item.description: type 2 MI includes detection of a rise and/or fall of cTn with at least one value above the 99th percentile and evidence of an imbalance between myocardial oxygen supply and demand unrelated to coronary thrombosis, requiring at least one of the following: Symptoms of acute myocardial ischemia; New ischemic ECG changes; Development of pathological Q waves; Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium, or new regional wall motion abnormality in a pattern consistent with an ischemic etiology.

item.title: type 3 myocardial infarction
item.description: type 3 myocardial infarction Cardiac death in patients with symptoms suggestive myocardialischaemia and presumed new ischaemic EcG changes before cTn values become available or abnormal meets criteria for type 3 MI

item.description: UIP usual interstitial PNA (IP) UIP imaging pattern: reticular opacities, honeycombing, traction bronchiectasis; peripheral, subpleural, & basal Sx >12 mo

item.title: Uremia
item.description: Uremia hemodialysis indication: pericarditis, encephalopathy, bleeding [[Residual syndrome]] Classical signs of uremia are: progressive weakness and easy fatigue, loss of appetite due to nausea and vomiting, muscle atrophy, tremors, abnormal mental function, frequent shallow respiration, and metabolic acidosis.

item.title: Uremic bleeding
item.description: Uremic bleeding Uremia ‚Üí platelet dysfunction including ‚Üì aggregation, impaired adhesiveness Treatment: dDAVP, cryoprecipitate, correct anemia (improves plt aggregation and adhesion by increasing plt interactions with endothelium), consider holding anti-plt agents

item.description: Urine Dipstick [[Specific gravity of Urine Dipstick]] [[pH of Urine Dipstick]] Range: 4.5‚Äì8.5; useful in evaluation of stones, RTAs, infection (urease UTI) [[Protein of Urine Dipstick]] Blood [[Workup-of-hematuria]] ‚äï from RBCs, free Hgb, or free myoglobin (eg, rhabdo) False ‚äï: semen, dilute urine (‚Üí osmotic cell lysis), ‚Üë pH, vaginal blood False ‚äñ: vit C WBC Suggests inflammation (UTI, interstitial nephritis, GN) Ketones Detects acetoacetate (ie, ketoacidosis) but not Œ≤-hydroxybutyrate Leuk est Lysed PMNs.

item.title: valve-replacement
item.description: valve-replacement (Circ 2021;143:e72) Based on symptoms: once they develop ‚Üí AVR needed Indicated in: sx severe (stage D1; D2; D3 if AS felt to be cause of sx); asx severe + EF <50% (stage C2); or severe (stage C1) and undergoing other cardiac surgery Reasonable if: asx severe (C1) but either sx or ‚Üì BP w/ exercise (can carefully exercise asx AS to uncover sx; do not exercise sx AS), very severe, ‚Üë BNP, rapid progression Growing data to support AVR in asx severe AS (NEJM 2020;382:111; Circ 2021;143:e72) Type of valve: mechanical reasonable if Pt <50 yrs, bioprosthetic if >65 yrs or cannot tolerate long-term anticoagulation; individualize if 50‚Äì65 yrs Transcatheter AoV implantation (TAVI, see below) attractive alternative to surgery Medical (if not AVR candidate or to temporize): careful diuresis prn, control HTN, maintain SR; digoxin if ‚Üì EF & HF or if AF; avoid venodilators (nitrates) & ‚äñ inotropes (Œ≤B/CCB) if severe AS; avoid vigorous physical exertion once AS mod‚Äìsevere ?

item.title: What are the most commonly encountered fever patterns
item.description: What are the most commonly encountered fever patterns Sustained or continued (little variability from day to day): this used to be the pattern of lobar pneumonia , steady until abruptly resolving by either crisis or death.

item.description: Whom to treat-venous thromboembolism (JAMA 2020;324:1765; Chest 2021;160:e545) Superficial venous thrombosis: elevate extremity, warm compresses, compression stockings, NSAIDs for sx.

item.title: wide complex
item.description: wide complex regular VT or unknown WCT try adenosine if no response then: [[amiodarone]] or procainamide or sotalol or lidocaine (if VT) & prepare for synch cardioversion

item.title: wide-complex tachycardias WCTS
item.description: wide-complex tachycardias (WCTS) [[Etiologies-wide-complex tachycardias (WCTS)]] [[Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (MMVT)]] [[Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (PMVT)]] [[Diagnostic clues that favor VT]] [[Long-term management-wide-complex tachycardias (WCTS)]]

item.title: Wilson disease
item.description: Wilson disease (World J Hepatol 2015;7:2859) Recessive disorder of copper transport (mutation in ATP7B) ‚Üí copper overload Epidemiology: 1 in ~30,000 w/ age of presentation generally ranging from 3 to 55 y

item.title: Wolff-Chaikoff effect
item.description: Wolff-Chaikoff effect Excess iodide transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification (step 2) In individuals with a normal thyroid, the gland escapes from this inhibitory effect In individuals with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease (Hashimoto’s thyroiditis or Graves’ disease), the suppressive effect may persist

item.title: woman health
item.description: woman health Contraception Vaginitis/Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs)/Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) Menstrual and Bleeding Disorders Menopause Preconception Care and Pregnancy Infertility Miscarriage and Abortion

item.title: Won‚Äôt Breathe as Etiologies of High elevated PaCO2
item.description: Won‚Äôt Breathe as Etiologies of High elevated PaCO2 decreae RR Respiratory Drive Voluntary hypervent. NI Pimax & A-a grad Metabolic alkalosis 1¬∞ neurologic: brain- stem stroke, tumor, 1¬∞ alveolar hypovent 2¬∞ neurologic: sedatives, CNS infxn, [[hypothyroidism]]

item.title: Workup for effusion
item.description: Workup for effusion r/o infxn: usually apparent from Hx & CXR; ? value of ‚úì acute and convalescent serologies

item.title: Workup for idiopathic VTE
item.description: Workup for idiopathic VTE (NEJM 2015;373:697) Thrombophilia workup ‚úì if ‚äï FH; may be helpful but consider timing as thrombus, heparin and warfarin Œî results Useful for relatives, if dx APLAS (given requires warfarin), or if not planning lifelong anticoagulation for Pt.

item.title: Workup for non-AG metabolic acidosis
item.description: Workup for non-AG metabolic acidosis Evaluate history for causes (see above) ‚úì urine anion gap (UAG) = (UNa + UK) ‚Äì UCl UAG = unmeasured anions ‚Äì unmeasured cations; NH4+ is primary unmeasured cation (represented by UCl).

item.title: Workup of acute hypoxemia
item.description: Workup of acute hypoxemia Cyanosis: when >5 g/dL of deoxygenated Hb in vessels of skin/mucous membranes. Central: ‚Üì SaO2 (pulm disease, shunt); abnl Hb [metHb, sulfHb, COHb (not true cyanosis)]

item.title: Workup of chronic diarrhea
item.description: Workup of chronic diarrhea positive: FOB WBC calprotectin lactoferrin Inflammatory: stool culture, colonoscopy positive: fecal fat Malabsorption: * Based on hx: ‚úî tissue transglut.

item.title: Workup-acid-base disturbances
item.description: Workup-acid-base disturbances Traditional or physiologic approach (Br√∏nsted-Lowry definition of acids & bases) Determine primary disorder: ‚úì pH, PaCO2, HCO3 Determine if degree of compensation is appropriate [[Compensation-for-Acid-Base-Disorders]] Alternative approaches Base excess/deficit (NEJM 2018;378:1419) ÂèÉËÄÉ‚û°Ô∏è Diagnostic use of base excess in acid‚Äìbase disorders [[Diagnostic Use of Base Excess in Acid‚ÄìBase Disorders]] Strong ion difference or ‚ÄúStewart Method‚Äù (NEJM 2014;371:1821)

item.title: Workup-acute kidney injury AKI
item.description: Workup-acute kidney injury (AKI) H&P: meds, contrast, or other nephrotoxins; ‚Üì PO intake, HoTN, infxn/sepsis; trauma, myalgias; BPH/retention. Search for insult 24‚Äì48 hr prior ‚Üë Cr.

item.title: Workup-acute liver failure
item.description: Workup-acute liver failure (Clin Liver Dis 2017;21:769) CBC, PT/PTT, LFTs, lytes, BUN/Cr, NH3, pH, arterial lactate, acetaminophen level, HIV, amylase/lipase, viral serologies (qv) in all Pts, with additional labs as below if suspected

item.title: Workup-cirrhosis
item.description: Workup-cirrhosis (Am J Gastro 2017;112:18; Lancet 2021;398:1359) Abd U/S w/ Doppler: liver size & echotexture, r/o HCC, ascites, ‚úì patency of vasculature

item.title: Workup-fever in a returned traveler
item.description: Workup-fever in a returned traveler Routine testing: CBC w/ diff, BMP, LFTs, BCx, UA, rapid malaria test Fever in a traveler from a malaria zone is malaria until proven otherwise; consider a medical emergency ‚Üí hospitalization & empiric Rx.

item.title: Workup-fever of unknown origin
item.description: Workup-fever of unknown origin Initial: CBC w/ diff, CMP, ESR, CRP, 3 sets BCx (off abx), U/A, UCx, CXR Additional workup based on sx: ANA, RF, cryoglobulin, LDH, CK/aldolase, SPEP, TFTs, PPD or IGRA, HIV Ag/Ab ¬± PCR, RPR, EBV serologies, CMV PCR, HBV/HCV serologies Consider imaging: chest & abd CT, tagged WBC scan, FDG-PET, TTE, LE duplex US Tissue dx: consider bx of LN (excisional preferred), liver (especially if ‚Üë Aœï), TA (for GCA), BM, kidney (RPGN)

item.title: Workup-for-AG-metabolic-acidosis
item.description: Workup-for-AG-metabolic-acidosis (AJKD 2021;78:A16) ‚úì for ketonuria (dipstick acetoacetate) or plasma Œ≤-hydroxybutyrate (Œ≤OHB) nb, urine acetoacetate often not present in early ketoacidosis due to shunting to Œ≤OHB; ‚à¥ acetoacetate may later turn ‚äï but does not signify worsening disease If ‚äñ ketones, ‚úì renal function, lactate, toxin screen, and [[Serum osmolal gap]] If obtunded or ‚Üë‚Üë AG, check osmolal gap (OG) = measured osmoles ‚Äì calculated osmoles Calculated osmoles = (2 √ó Na) + (glucose/18) + (BUN/2.

item.title: Workup-glomerulonephritis
item.description: Workup-glomerulonephritis (JAMA 2017;318:1276) Acute GN/RPGN ¬± lung hemorrhage is an emergency ‚Üí requires early Dx and Rx UA + sediment (dysmorphic RBCs) ‚úì ANCA, anti-GBM, C3/C4, SPEP, serum FLC

item.title: Workup-hyperkalemia
item.description: Workup-hyperkalemia (Crit Care Med 2008;36:3246) Rule out pseudohyperkalemia (IVF w/ K, tourniquet, hemolysis, ‚Üë plt or WBC), rule out transcellular shift

item.title: Workup-hypernatremia
item.description: Workup-hypernatremia ‚úì Uosm, UNa, volume status (vital signs, orthostatics, JVP, skin turgor, BUN, Cr)

item.title: Workup-hypokalemia
item.description: Workup-hypokalemia (JAMA 2021;12:1216) Identify transcellular shifts & treat. TTKG validity questioned (Curr Op Nephro 2011;20:547). ‚úì UK:Cr: >13 mEq/g ‚Üí renal loss; <13 mEq/g ‚Üí extrarenal loss (AJKD 2019;74:682)

item.title: workup-hyponatremia
item.description: workup-hyponatremia (JASN 2012;23:1140 & 2017;28:1340; Crit Care 2013;17:206; NEJM 2015;372:55) Workup History: acute vs. chronic (>48 h); sx severity; risk for neuro complications (alcoholism, malnourished, cirrhosis, older women on thiazides, hypoxia, hypoK) [[Measure plasma osmolality]] For hypotonic hyponatremia, ‚úì [[volume status]] [[Measure Uosm]] If euvolemic and ‚Üë Uosm, evaluate for glucocorticoid insufficiency and hypothyroidism If available, consider FEUricAcid as >12% suggests SIADH (J Clinc Endo 2008;93:2991) BacklinkÔºö [[sodium and water homeostasis]]

item.title: Workup-nephrolithiasis
item.description: Workup-nephrolithiasis Non-contrast CT 97% Se, 96% Sp (ureteral dilation w/o stone suggests recent passage); U/S (Se 57%, Sp 98%) may serve as initial test in stable patient (NEJM 2014;371:1100)

item.title: Workup-nephrotic syndrome
item.description: Workup-nephrotic syndrome (BMJ 2008;336:1185) U/A + sediment: usually benign; ¬± oval fat bodies (‚ÄúMaltese crosses‚Äù; NEJM 2007;357:806) Measure proteinuria: 24-h urine or spot urine protein/Cr ratio (not accurate in AKI), renal bx

item.title: Workup-of-hematuria
item.description: Workup-of-hematuria (NEJM 2021;385:153) Urine dipstick: ‚äï if ‚â•3 RBCs; ‚äï dipstick and ‚äñ sediment ‚Üí myo- or hemoglobinuria

item.title: Workup-syncope
item.description: Workup-syncope (etiology cannot be determined in ~40% of cases) (JAMA 2019;321:2448) H&P incl. orthostatic VS have highest yield and most cost effective R/o life-threatening dx including: cardiac syncope, severe blood loss, PE, SAH History (from Pt and witnesses if available) activity and posture before the incident precipitating factors: exertion (AS, HCMP, PHT), positional ‚àÜ (orthostatic HoTN), stressors such as sight of blood, pain, emotional distress, fatigue, prolonged standing, warm environment, N/V, cough/deglutition/micturition/defecation (neurocardiogenic), head turning or shaving (carotid sinus hypersens.

item.description: Zygomycetes Epidemiology: diabetes (espec. those w/ prior DKA), heme malignancy, neutropenia, transplant, chronic steroids, iron overload, trauma, h/o voriconazole Rx or Ppx Clinical: rhinocerebral = severe periorbital/facial pain, swelling, vision changes, sinusitis, opthalmoplegia, nasal ulcerations/ necrosis, HA.

item.description: Œ±1-antitrypsin deficiency early-onset panacinar emphysema or signif basilar disease, 1‚Äì3% of COPD cases. Suspect if age <45, lower lungs affected,

item.title: Œ±1-antitrypsin deficiency Œ±1-AT
item.description: Œ±1-antitrypsin deficiency (Œ±1-AT) (J Hepatol 2016;65:413; NEJM 2020;382:1443) Abnl Œ±1-AT ‚Üí polymerization in liver (cirrhosis) & uninhibited protease activity in lung (emphysema).
